The Impro.Tour.S  Project is submitted by IAL Toscana Vocational Training Organization, coordinator of the Project Consortium that brings together 4 VET Secondary School in the area of Massa Carrara, Lucca and Pisa in the Tourism and Catering sector with the main aim to answer the need for Training and facilitating young people and student in entering the labour market in these 3 Provinces,  which are identified like “industrial district in crisis” of the Tuscany Region North coast area. In the Economic Report of Tuscan Region 2014 the tourism and catering sector on the tuscan area, particularly in the 3 provinces mentioned above, shows a decline in tourism demand in the recent years.
The needs analysis made by IRPET the Regional Institute for statistic research and study has been confirmed by the companies, from which We have received letters of support and commitment (see attached) to hire people who have had workexperiences with this project. 
General objectives of Impro.Tour.S  are: improving skills in the tourism sector as requested by the job market always changing; developing a stronger language skills in answer to companies needs to have staff with fluent languages; structuring a system to recognizing credits acquired by mobility and transferring them through education/ vocational training /labour market systems in transparency; developing international partnerships able to manage these particular young target groups; writing an handbook for validating mobility activities and recognizing credits from the beginning to the end of the work experiences, putting together in a whole system different certification’s tools coming from different worlds of education and vocational training..
The Project Consortium has selected 6 international partners, with whom has collaborated in the past, and which have strong connections with enterprises in the Tourism and catering sector and big experience in hosting students and young people groups. The Consortium has choosen countries and city centers with a strong calling to tourism so that participants could have a real and effective workexperience. 
With these host partners the mobility management is regulated on the base of a MoU which sets the framework for credit transfer and where there are defined the LO to be assessed, validate and recognized. Besides, the Project Consortium will make a LA which will define which  knowledge and skills should be acquired and finally evaluated. 
Impro.Tour.S  Project will realize 2 mobility paths directed to 2 different target groups, with different ages and L.O.: gr.1 (age16/19) are school’s students, both in the tourism and catering sector, will have a workexperience abroad for 4 weeks; Gr.2 new graduates and newqualificated in tourism and catering sector young people, age 18/20, (realize the workexperience abroad within 1 year from the releasing of the diploma), for this target group the period abroad will be 12 weeks, this has been estimated an appropriated time for developing technical and soft skills, needed to enter the labour market. 
The Consortium has considered that having a mobility experience in sme’s for young students and new graduates is an opportunity to check their skills in the partners’ countries tourism and catering sector: in UK, Spain, Germany, Ireland, Czech Republic and France. The choice of a placement in sme’s and not in big multinational is a specific decision, to give participants a very similar experience to the one They could have in North Tuscany Coast companies and having the idea of which kind of job opportunity They will find in the small enterprises. 
Starting from the selection and a first step of guidance before the leaving, the project’s activities will be focused on the workexperience abroad, where each company tutor will take care of monitoring participants’ skills learning on the workplace, through an employers’ evaluation form, provided by the Consortium. 
One accompanying person/tutor will leave with the school students and course’s participants groups, who are age 16/18: accompanying person/tutor is foreseen each 10 students. At the end of the mobility experience all groups will have improved their skills: professional,cultural, linguistic and relational abilities, self esteem, personal growing, communication, adaptability, flexibility problem solving skills. Consortium members will developed their knowledge as well. Concerning the managing of a trasnational partnership and the ECVET system of evaluation and recognizing learning outcomes and credits, and They will elaborate and handbook about these themes.The final seminar foreseen will be the occasion which will create long term effects and stimulate a change on the area about labour market active policies and school’s didactic programs.

The ET project has two main aims. Firstly to provide teaching experience for newly qualified teachers of English as a Foreign Language to enhance their employment prospect. Secondly to provide English Language teaching to learners who may receive little or no English Language teaching, especially from native speakers.There is also a sub aim of discovering the changes in the English Language teaching market in Europe with the implementation of CLIL and the technological changes in the teaching of English in Spain Italy and Portugal, and how that needs to be reflected in the teaching training offered on the courses for becoming a teacher of English.Language Link trains over 200 English language teachers every year and adding the experience of teaching in a formal setting in Spain, Italy or Portugal will provide a boost to their CV's and their opportunities for employment. This is especially true for the newly qualified teachers whose ethnic background is not European.The participants in the project will be 60 newly qualified teachers who have completed, at Language Link or in any of the organisations in the consortium, in the last 12 months, the Certificate for Teaching English Language to Adults . This course does include a component on teaching young learners. The participants will be over 21 and generally hold a university degree or equivalent.The participants will carry out English Language teaching in a variety of contexts. Please see attached case studies for a more detailed description. In summary they will teach English Language in state schools to children, to adults, to workers in the Tourism and Hospitality industries, to the unemployed and to migrants. There is a great need and desire to learn English as way of improving employability, mobility and communication in Spain, Italy and Portugal.The processes to carry out the project will include: The publicizing process, the selection process, the preparation process, the logistics of travel, accommodation, insurance etc, the monitoring process, the evaluation process and the dissemination processThe main long term impact of this project will be twofold. Firstly the newly qualified teachers who participate will have greatly enhanced chances of gaining their first paid teaching post, in Britain, or especially in Europe or internationally.  Secondly the learners of English, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds, in Italy, Spain and Portugal will experience English Language teaching from qualified, enthusiastic teachers. Their will also be an impact upon the future training of English as a Foreign Language teachers as the impact of CLIL and the technological changes in the teaching of English in European countries such as Spain, Italy and Portugal is better understood.

The aims of the project as well as foreseen activities meet our school‘s transnational strategy and tasks.
The activities based on Klaipeda Tourism School‘s transnational strategy are following:
 1. Further initiation and implementation of international projects, encouragement of co-operation between companies and our school, providing teachers and students with opportunities to take over technological innovations, putting emphasis on multiculturalism.
2. Our students, teachers and administration will be provided with opportunities to participate in exchange programmes and professional mastery contests. 
3. The school will be an active host organisation for students and teachers who participate in Erasmus+ based projects.  
4. Co-operation with business company is of great importance. Foreign specialists of various professions will be invited to give lectures at school.
5. Participation in international mastery contests will be continued.  
6. There will be co-operation with partners from Denmark, the Netherlands, The United Kingdom and Southern Europe. 
7. Mentorship and quality of the projects are to be intensified.
8. Vocational teachers and school workers will be able to improve their knowledge of the English language. 
 
46 students and 26 teachers/staff are planned to be sent to participate in practical training. 1 visit from Italy to give a lectures is due in 2018. 
Our school is reconsidering its partners‘ circle, some visits to the Netherlands, Denmark, Portugal have been planned. The school‘s aim is a more intensive co-operation with other vocational schools. ECVET application elements are being co-ordinated with host partners, a higher students‘ skill recognition is to be achieved.  
According to a partial transnational strategy, students will be sent to participate in practical training. The professions are following: cook, waiter/bartender, confectioner, recreation services agent. The students of the mentioned professions will visit: Spain, 7 students at a time (2 flows); 8 students will visit the United Kingdom, 4 students at a time (2 flows); 7 students, studying cooking and confectionery, will visit Italy, 5 confectioners will visit Denmark, 4 cooks, waiters/bartenders/confectioners will visit the Netherlands, 6 students, will visit Portugal. Accompanying teachers will be supervising students during the first week of the visit and will solve any problems related to the programme, accommodation, catering or local transportation. Long-distance journeys with changes have been planned. 
Two Erasmus PRO-long term mobilities are planned, two participants (cooks) will go to United Kingdom to work in a restaurant for 3 month period.
Recognition of academic achievements: host partners will define academic results applying ECVET elements. Once students are back to school, the results will be transferred to their journal, part of the practical training will be credited according to topics set in advance by vocational teachers, host organisation and participant. 
The following ECVET  elements will be used: an agreement and signing the Mutual Understanding Memorandum with partners is to be achieved. Practical training agreements will be signed by three parties, i.e. sending organisation, host organisation and participant. 
Teachers will visit the Netherlands, Spain, the United Kingdom and Portugal. Teachers are interested in getting more information about apprenticeship and developing their skills as these things are related to needs of  school, labour market in Lithuania. Participants will visit vocational schools which have similar training programmes alongside companies which accept apprentices and provide on-the-job training. Colleagues‘ work, organisation of practical training , evaluation/self-evaluation papers, supervision of apprentices will be observed and discussed.  Vocational teachers and school representatives will get acquainted with education system, organisation of practical training at school and companies, the forms of apprenticeship. These visits will be considered as professional development, teachers will be asked to describe the impact and present innovations to school‘s community.  
According to the strategy, our school aims to help vocational teachers improve the knowledge of foreign languages. Up to 20 teachers will attend English course in 2018.
The effect of the project is that vocational teachers will develop their professional skills, refresh teaching content, share their experience, organise mastery contests. The school‘s staff and administration will apply certain forms of apprenticeship, make changes in teaching programmes. They will also improve  management, organisational and language skills.

The project “Transiti” is promoted by Ce.S.F.Or. that has already successfully realized IVT and PLM mobility projects within the framework of the Leonardo da Vinci Programme , in the tourism, hotel and catering field. 

The project Consortium is made of public and private organizations and covers the regions of Central and Southern Italy, in which  high rates of youth unemployment can be found .The project  supports the objectives of the "Europe 2020" strategy for growth and employment of European citizens, contributes to the mobility and employability of young people to support their entry into the labor market and supports the objectives of the Strategic Framework for European cooperation in the field education and Training (Educational training 2020). It promotes lifelong learning and mobility of young people in European Countries and  meets the needs of training and mobility of both young learners of the South Centre (Lazio, Campania, Calabria, Sicily) and of  newly  graduates (Lazio Region) that are attending or have attended training paths in the Tourism and catering field. 

"Transiti" has the following objectives: 

- integrate the course of study in the hospitality industry with a practical activity (internship), realizing 95 new mobility of learners and graduates in European companies in the sector; 

-strengthen  the personal and professional dimension of  young people involved in the project; 

- increase the capacity and European dimension of the  organizations active in the field of Education and Training 

- strengthen cooperation and synergies among  the organizations involved in European mobility and the companies

- increase  the use of national and European tools and implement procedures for the recognition of competences and skills 

- improve and strengthen the language skills of young learners 

- raise awareness of European citizenship and intercultural skills of the participants.

The project will last two years, from October 2014 to September 2016. The internships will last three weeks and will be carried out  with  companies of the sector, as identified by the project partners (Receiving organizations) in 7 European countries: UK, Ireland, Spain, Germany, France, Portugal and Poland. Will be realized:  95 mobility of young learners and 12 mobilities of accompayning  persons. The target group is represented by:

1) 85 young students included in the training programs of technical and professional institutes( tourism and hotel )/ vocational Training Centres partners in the project.

2) 10 graduates residing in the Lazio Region who graduated at Tourism Institutes or vocational training  Centres less than 12 months ago

The selection will be made among candidates attending training courses  which provide  the following professional  profiles: assistant chef, waiter, receptionist.

Ce.S.F.Or., Coordinator of the National VET Consortium, shared strategic objectives and tasks of the project with all the partners; the learning outcomes previously defined have been agreed and  the ECVET procedure for the recognition of credits  to the participants has been implemented. As for  mobility ,  the methodology and tools applied are the ones  already successfully used in other European projects (EuroCaThos, MasterMOB). For the implementation of the activities , has been choosen the methodology of  "matrixes of responsibility" that allows to identify for each partner, activities, tasks , timing, and professionals involved.

The expected outcomes for participants in the project are: the acquisition of new technical skills in the field of reference; the acquisition of transversal skills; the improvement of language skills and the acquisition of national and European certifications to be spent on the European labor market (Europass, ECVET ); a greater knowledge of  job opportunities in EU countries. The partner organizations of the project will:implement innovative procedures for the management of mobility; broaden their networks and contacts in Europe,  increase their range of activities and innovative programs (attractiveness of organizations) to  meet  the needs of young people interested in the experiences of European mobility in a better way.

Generally speaking, "Transiti" will have a positive long-term  effect on the organisations and their staff: tutor, project manager,training and mobility coordinators, administrative clerks.  Tools  and procedures to  guarantee certification and validation of  formative credits and tools for planning mobilities will be implemented. Furthermore, the companies of tourism, hotel and catering field on regional, national and  European level may benefit from more qualified and trained professional profiles.

The project will realize the internationalization activities as foreseen in the 2016 Ce.S.F.Or. operative plan; Ce.S.F.Or. (applicant) will realize mobility activities in the following fields: tourism and catering, communication and marketing, creative industry, cultural industry, for learners and staff; the project duration will be of 24 months. The mobility will be realized in 5 EU Countries: United Kingdom, Ireland, Spain, Portugal and France, in organizations/SME within Ce.S.F.Or. European network, and with the inclusion of new partners, in order to widen the European network as described within the goals of the internationalization strategy. The mobility activity will involve n. 50 learners and 6 accompanying persons for learners under 18 years old, and n. 5 staff. It will be realized an activity of VET learners traineeships in companies abroad, with a duration of 21 days, travel days included, for n. 40 learners and 6 accompanying persons, and an activity of VET learners traineeships in companies abroad with a duration of 92 days, travel days included, for n. 10 learners. Moreover, it will be realized an activity of staff training abroad with a duration of 7 days, travel days included, for n. 5 staff, with the aim of enhancing the language and intercultural competences of the staff involved in the mobility. The activities are consistent with the strategic choices to support the objectives of the internationalization strategy 2015-2020. At the end of the mobility will be realized an activity of guidance for the inclusion in the labour market of all the learners that took part in the project.Ce.S.F.Or. will realize the mobility activities for learners and staff of its own organization; moreover will also give the opportunity to other learners and staff, to realize European mobility activities, through a public call and its publicity.Operating modalities:Realization of a public call and its publicity for the participation of learners and staff in the European mobility activities; the call will foresee:The territory of reference described in the internationalization plan;The target group that could participate in the mobility (learners and staff), in compliance with the rules foreseen in the Erasmus+ 2016 Programme in the VET learners and staff mobility with VET mobility Charter measure;number of learners and staff that will participate in the European mobility;The professional profiles;The EU Countries where the mobility activities will be realized;The kind of mobility activities to be realized (VET learners traineeship in companies abroad and/or staff training abroad).For what concerns the preparation modalities, please make reference to the description included in the VET Mobility Charter e-form – section E.2.4For what concerns the Project Management, please make reference to the section E.2.1 of the VET Mobility Charter e-form.In attachment, n. 6 Memorandum of Understanding agreed with the project partnership, in order to implement the ECVET procedures.

Our mobility project for job-seekers within the framework of Erasmus+ takes into account ten principles of the European quality commitment for mobility. 

The regional council of Basse Normandie is widely supporting this project since it answers to its strategy of openness towards Europe and the world. The Region wishes to develop its international exchange programmes and especially company internships in Europe to allow job-seekers to get a faster occupational integration (80 % during the last programs). By bringing its financial support to this project, the French Region of Low Normandy shows its interest and its will to collaborate in the placement of job-seekers



A Steering committee that consists of an executive of Pôle emploi Basse Normandie, representatives of the French Region Low Normandy and advisers of the PEI ( International Employment Agency), determines a protocol of implementation concerning the choice of countries, the contents of the stay in host countries, the administrative aspect (social welfare) and the remuneration for the trainees, the selection of the partners and the participants, the financing of the program, the follow-up of the action, the qualitative and financial balance assessment.



This program is directed by the contractor which leans on sending partners and host partners based in European countries. The host partner is appointed by the contractor to build-up a real network of local companies interested in the European mobility of the workers and presenting the need for staff. There are several companies interested in receiving interns. Thanks to 19 years of European experience, we benefit from a wide network of companies in most of the European countries, facilitating the placement of the trainees. 

Regular contacts between the various partners, the beneficiaries, and companies will facilitate a continuous monitoring of the project.



Individual and group evaluations will allow us to measure the gap between the initial project and its realization. 



Living and working in another country of the European Economic Area will allow job-seekers to:

• Better match the needs of companies, to strengthen their professional and linguistic skills in a different professional environment 

• Discover new techniques, new fields of experience, 

• Know new cultures and another way of company organisation  

• Become integrated as soon as possible within the European labour market, 

• Develop new employment prospects, 

• Be more autonomous. 



Moreover, this project allows young job-seekers to live a first work experience in Europe in a context where job offers target only experienced people. This type of programme is often the response to their integration preoccupations. A mobility experience is a real asset to build employment pathway in Europe. All sectors can be concerned. The potential beneficiaries will be informed through posters in the different employment areas (Pôle emploi, local missions, youth areas,…) during employment forums an through www.pole-emploi.fr.



We will specifically target job-seekers with level IV diploma that didn’t already benefit from a training course in Europe and that know some occupational integration difficulties. 



The French Region Low Normandy participates financially in this programme and allows the participants to have the intern in vocational training status so they can obtain remuneration during these 9 weeks. 

In their return, the candidates will have to write a report and will get a certificate of internship in complement to the EUROPASS. A final balance assessment will be realized by the contractor and send to all our partners and financiers.



The intended impact of this project is to get an occupational integration of the targeted public. Indeed, this immersion in a company will be a determining factor in the professional evolution of the candidates. It will allow either integration in the host country, or additional assets for an occupational integration back in France.

The impact of this program also concerns the interest of the politics to participate to this kind of action, to build a partners' network specialized in candidates' reception.



This year, countries aimed by this program are: Germany, Spain, Ireland, Italy, Malta and the United Kingdom.
MobiTec: mobilità nel settore del commercio e delle produzioni tessili e sartoriali

The proposal is devoted to 50 students coming from the Sismondi&Pacinotti School, specifically belonging to the 4th year of studies. In the way of going on according with the dual system (study and placement), the project has the aim of increasing abilities in order to afford the job markets enquiries and gain maturity and self indipendence in choosing better solution for studies and jobs.

Needs of participants are mainly:

-acquire and improve linguistic skills

-improve key competences

-improve and development job skills

-be competitive and prepared to enter into the job market at the end of the studies

Aims of the project for the participants are:

-a development as individuals and professionals

-acquire a good level of independence

-self critic power

-a good level of autonomy in the daily life.

Aim of the promoter is:

-develop its vocational training offer 

-enforce skills and abilities of the students

-offer innovative and quality trainings

Aim of the project applicant and partners is:

-develop networks in order to implement mobility projects

-increase the quality in school system and in enterprises 

Attended results by the project:

-participants acquire more in terms of key competences and professional skills in the way they can more easily enter the job market, with right qualifications, high motivation and high self consideration

-local enterprise improve quality of their services, giving place to new profiles, prepared and qualified

-international partners and sending partner improve educational methods and instruments, together with POF, focusing on dual system of education (theory-practise, classroom and placement).

The project intends to offer a mobility opportunity  to 50  students from the 4th year of study: specifically the 50 students have already gained the qualification at the end of the third year of study and, at the moment of the mobility, are attending the 2 years of specialisation. The students are so divided in:

-10 students qualified as secreterian and front desk operator

-10 students qualified as front desk operator in tourism (promoter and welcom operator)

-15 students qualified as operator in textile and fashion

-15 students qualified as elechtronic and elechtrician operator

The experience will be composed of two main phases:

-first phase: taking place for the entire duration of the experience abroad and oriented to linguistic and cultural apprentship.

-second phase: during which the participants will have the opportunity to live the economic and local life. Local enterprises in the frame of commerce,tourism and management, fashion industry and mechanic/elechtronic will host beneficiaries with the aim of completing their vocational training, linguistic preparation and personal grow. 

The mobility will take place in two macro-flows during 2015 e 2016, with a duration of 4 weeks in Great Britain and France the first (2015) and Malta the second (2016).The involved countries are economically close to tourism and with SME’s, both with mother tongue relevant for an European employability. The project will take place with a durations of 24 months.

These tasks were foreseen for development of internalisation:
1.To iniciate and implement international projects, to encourage interaction between school and companies, to create conditions for teachers and students to adopt technological inovations, foster entrepreneurship, multiculturalism. 
2.To create conditions for teachers and students to participate in exhange programmes and skill competitions.
3.To be a host organisation in Erasmus+ projects, to organise  exhange programmes for incoming teachers and students, to share the best experience.
4.To cooperate with business companies, to participate in projects together. To invite professionals-lecturers from abroad.
5.To intensify cooperation with partners from North and South Europe, United Kingdom.
6.To strenghten mentoring, assurance of the quality in projects.
Plan is to send 40 students and 24  teachers for placements. One incoming teaching visits is planned (from Italy).
Partnerships with Belgium,  Portugal, France are updated, closer cooperation with vocational schools. ECVET elements are negotiated  with the host partners, in order to reach better students‘ achievements recognition.
It is planned to send various specialties students, according to internalisation strategy. Cooks, waiters and bartenders, confectioners, recreational service workers,  sport club activities organizers will go to placements. They  will go to Spain (2 flows 7 students in one flow), 10 students to United Kingdom, 10 cooks to Italy, 6 students to Portugal. It is planned to send leading teachers to all countries.
Teachers will go to a job shadowing visits to Belgium, Spain, United Kingdom and France. Participants will visit vocational schools with similar teaching programmes and basis. Topic of the visits: assurance of vocational training quality. They will observe colleagues‘ work, discuss practical training organisation issues, evaluation and self-evaluation documents, help and mentoring of pupils. Vocational teachers and administration will go to visits, they  learn about educational systems, quality management, plan further students‘ placements. Teachers‘ visits will be recognised as improvement of   qualification, they will be asked to describe the impact and present new experience to colleagues, students.
Host partners will describe students‘ results using ECVET elements. Marks and results will be transfered to a student diary, as part of practical training abroad, it will be recognised, according to agreed topics with vocational teacher, host organisation, and a participant  in advance. Project coordinator, vocational teachers and mentor will cooperate.
ECVET elements will be used: memorandum of understanding will be discussed and signed with host partners. Learning agreements will be signed (sending, host organisations and participants will sign them), description of learning outcomes. It is planned to recognise learning outcomes acquired in non-formal way too. Host partners will issue recomendations for participants, according to their skills.
Project impact: vocational teachers improve their qualification, reflect on teaching content, share expierence, organise skill competitions, events. Administration staff share experience, update and create teaching programmes, improve management, project organisational, foreign language skills. Teachers will get experience how to promote motivation, use personalisation and differentiation.  Participants are  interested in skills and competencies important  for students‘ future career.
School improves status in region, is becoming more open and atractive  to society, social partners, promotes vocational training. 
Impact for students: vocational training according to international standarts, competitiveness of  specialties in Lithuania,  training  orientated to career, opportunities to know other cultures, sociocultural environment, to improve foreign language skills.
Project dissemination  activities. Participants will prepare reports, present gained experience, knowledge to teachers, trainers and community. Teachers  will prepare reports, give open lessons, events. Presentations will be given in methodological groups,  during teachers‘ meetings. Stands about project will be prepared for community. The final meeting will be organized after implementation of the project, representatives of  vocational  schools, social partners will be invited. Information will be shared during  „Open doors“ events at school. Foreign partners will disseminate project activities in their social networks, websites.

More than 35% of students regret within one year their job or choice of studies. Students often don't know what they want or don't know their options. They go through an unclear orientation phase and decide at the last moment. Drop-out rates are extremely high.  Students in vocational training are confronted with a professional choice that doesn't suit them at all.
All these students need better guidance regarding  their possibilities. As a school we have the responsibility to support them during this process. students should be able to testdrive the sector of their choice during an internship in different working situations. This helps students to asses the different aspects from their future professional life.
During internships new compettences will be developed. Students experience companyculture and learn to cope with the demands of employers. They learn to engage actively in their own future.
The feedback from both participants and workplacements are invaluable for the school itself to evaluate their own programs, but also for the function it has as a job-orientation counselor. Accompanying persons can spot new trends, technologies ad practices and bring these new ideas back to the school.
On a yearly base students of the program 'managing and undertaking' get the opportunity at a 2 week internship in companies in Londen. Students of industrial cooking of the fifth year undergo  a cooking internship in Greece. Students of the sixth year get the opportunity to go to the far North, Norway.

A. Number of students and profile:

The project is planned for the school years 2014-15 and 2015-2016, each time for 10 students of Commercial, 5 of Aesthetic Body Care and 10 of Hairstyling.

Commercial: this project and work experience prepares them for the labour market while also giving  them the maturity required for possible higher education.

Beauty Therapy: this specialisation year after secondary education on the one hand allows them to acquire more professional maturity in order to apply for a  job or to start a business of their own. Others will opt for further education. For those as well, this project will prove of extra value.

Hairstyling: this work experience will allow them to become proficient in their job in the course of 1 year. In this training, the main emphasis is on salon management, offering them the stock-in-trade to start up their own business. These students usually have a learning disorder, or have a limited ability to solve problems of a theoretical nature. However, they are clever with their hands and often turn out to be talented in the exercise of their profession. Their London work experience will enable them to enhance their skills even more.

Hardly any of these students can afford an internship like that. That  is why we apply for this support for them. The opportunity of a work experience abroad is treated as an essential part in the planning of this training. They will be able to obtain a reference which will undoubtedly be an asset when applying for a suitable job. The ability to do things independently, together with other essential skills and attitudes like showing respect and appreciation, admitting oneself to be in the wrong or unable to do something, accepting criticism and learning from it, communicating in an acceptable way: these are values which will last throughout their further career.

Communicating in a foreign language will definitely be quite a challenge for these technical and vocational students, but it will also prove to be an important asset. 

B. The Project Background

This project is a continuation of previous Leonardo Da Vinci projects. We have already been to London the last 3 years. A lot of energy has been put into this project, both by the school and the hosting partners. This project has continuously been refined , so that we have now attained the level where we can actually enjoy the benefits of our intense contacts. Therefore we would very much like to continue this project for another 2 years before looking out for a different destination.

C. Activities

1. Preliminary phase and selection of the candidates

- the students have to draw up a portfolio in which they introduce themselves and motivate why they want to participate in the project.

-Interview in Dutch and English. 

Based on this interview and the portfolio, the participants are selected.

- a 3-day team-building activity

- 2 info moments for students and parents , partly prepared by the students

- Final selection: after the team-building period and info with the parents, the definitive selection is made

2. The actual internship: The students will do a 3-week internship during the periods March-April of 2015 and 2016. Accompanied by 3 teachers, they depart together on the Eurostar. They stay in serviced apartments. These are apartments with one or two bedrooms and their own kitchen, which improves their ability to be self-sufficient. They are expected at their trainee posts 5 days a week. They have to get there by Tube. The teachers are there to help them with their problems, but also to evaluate them during their internship. Each students is evaluated by the trainee supervisor at the trainee post and by the supervising teachers.

3. Discussion and evaluation

After their London work experience, each student has to fill in their evaluation in the Ecas System. In addition, there is a more detailed evaluation by both students and supervising teachers.

Another assignment for the students is to inform and enthuse the new batch, their ‘successors’, for a work experience abroad.

D. Project results: the project plays an important part in the promotion of the different courses offered by our school. It is quite uncommon for students from technical and vocational directions to do a London work experience. Therefore this meets with a lot of response in our town and neighbouring  municipalities through the local press and their own trainee posts. Even schools from different school  communities like to ask for our expert advice in this field.

We look forward to being allowed to set up our project ‘competence-directed internships in London’ for the next 2 years and we hope to be granted the necessary subsidy to do so.

"Cultivating Europe" originates from the Institute’s need for more internationalization in response to the geographical marginality and distance from large urban centers, which causes a strong isolation of the population, especially the school that is characterized by limited relationships and stimulations. The Omni-Inclusive Institute located in Marsicovetere, which acts such as a  gravitational center of civic, cultural, creative exchanges, needs greater openness towards its own territory, to the country and Europe in general.
The Institute’s need to promote and encourage cooperation in all of its forms as essential element in the development of its educational system, was made evident in the POF and it was drawn up after a detailed analysis of students’ training needs, and it is considered necessary especially in response to the European development plan, outlined by the project staff. Concrete data show very high percentages of low academic performance in scientific and technical subjects (70% of pupils in primary and secondary schools and 35 % of students of the ITA, with a peak of 43% in the fourth grade) and the need to take action, starting from kindergarten, through adequate responses to special educational needs for the prevention of possible criticisms (in nursery school, 6.8% of children show already special educational needs).
Therefore, considering these training needs and in order to acquire new teaching models for a more cooperative and practical didactics, further it is able to involve students, enhancing their resources and paying attention to their needs, the project involves 25 teachers for job shadowing activities and structured courses in the UK, France and Malta for a period of 17 days, including 2 days of travel. In particular, the outlined plan of organization expects  the improvement of teachers’ knowledges, skills and abilities through targeted training activities that share the goal of re-structuring the educational curriculum and the consequent strengthening of  teaching.
In fact, the project intends, at the end of the experience, to proceed towards the formulation of a new vertical curriculum, applicable to all types and levels, born out of the internationalization experience and able to offer students the opportunity to improve their academic performance, combining knowledge and action. Therefore, the project staff, after an operative meeting, has defined the following objectives: developing a new vertical curriculum applicable to all types and levels of education; integrating CLIL methodology within daily training plan; implementing innovative training methods for DL: tasked based learning and cooperative learning; improving the knowledge of a foreign language; enhancing the digital skills of teachers in order to integrate new technologies in education and creating opportunities for debates and collaborations; adequately responding to special demands of attention; enhancing teaching skills for more innovative teaching and learning processes so as to meet the national established guidelines; transferring to students the knowledge acquired abroad; increasing the awareness and use of learning materials regarding the issues of environmental education and, in particular, of the agri-food and wine industry.
As a result of this project, 4 workshop activities will be activated: 1 Lab for children of kindergarten, two workshops focusing on issues such as viticulture and intended for pupils of primary and secondary levels and second degree and 1 language laboratory, aimed at creating a direct contact between the students of the sending institute and the pupils from the partner institutions. 2 didactic units will also be integrated in curricular lessons and they will be in CLIL mode (tasked based learning and cooperative learning methodologies). After the mobility and the activities that will be implemented within the Institute, it is expected, in terms of impact and in response to the European development plan, that teachers will be able, with the help of new methods, to improve the academic performance of pupils at least of 50% and to affect positively on 80% of the special attention requests coming from the nursery school. It is also expected a wider openness to the territory,  the country and Europe in general.

The future of tourism depends on the quality of service and compliance of initial   training of the employees with the  needs of hospitality business. The employees need more general and practical skills-greeting the customers, politeness of serving people, motivation to work.  The question of ensuring the quality of vocational teaching becomes more and more actual. The quality of teaching means suitability of conditions to enhance pupils’ self-education and their readiness to compete in the changing labor market, evaluating set quality requirements, goals and society needs. It is an integral part of teacher-student interaction and affects the high standard of training (learning) outcomes.
We face external and internal barriers as vocational training still doesn’t have prestige in the society. Vocational studies are chosen by pupils who can’t study in gymnasiums, colleges or universities. Low motivation of pupils, coming from faraway districts and misunderstanding their needs  influences the quality of teaching. Sometimes low qualification of teachers and lack of knowledge of new work technologies is also  to blame.
After finishing the school with the qualification of Hotel worker, the school graduates will work in hotels, guest houses, motels. Hotel worker teaching program is prepared on the bases of a model of European countries, where the employee is trained and has practice in a hotel, that’s why he is competent in the fallowing spheres:
1. Hotel housekeeping
2. Cooking in the hotel catering firm (bar, restaurant)
3. Serving hotel restaurant customers
Recreation and services agents have placements and work in a hotel reception, they have to learn how to arrange accomodation, how to plan tours. They have knowledge about catering, work of a hotel, how to organise trips, are able to provide information to guests.
The participants of this project also study these subjects (70% of teaching time is for practical learning). The modern concept of hospitality is very dynamic. Hotel guests’ needs are changing, requirements are increasing , so the service is individualized. Pupils in Klaipėda Tourism School have school-based practical learning in a hotel, bar and bar kitchen. After getting main skills, they continue practical training and work in cafes and hotels in Klaipėda, Palanga and Nida where they serve tourists from Lithuania, Europe and Russia.
We try to enable our pupils to find out and  feel what the concept of a highly skilled hotel worker is and to help them seek career in Lithuanian or European hotels. They need to know hotel housekeeping rules, prepare simple dishes and drinks, be aware of national cuisine and traditions, speak some foreign languages and be polite.
Aims: 3 vocational school pupils will go to 4 weeks placement in Germany, Unitied Kingdom, Italy and Spain hotels. During placement, pupils will be provided with teaching program and it will be considered to be the practice they need at school. The project will improve all skills required for the hotel worker. Back at school the pupils will disseminate knowledge and information, show their skills to teachers and schoolmates.
The project lasts 18 months.
Results: Deepened hotel worker skills and competence, possibility to know the requirements of hospitality business of a certain country, technologies used, possibility to improve foreign language skill. This will encourage the pupils of schools –participants to be motivated and competitive in the labor market or continue their studies in a chosen sphere.
Strong international links will continue to develop, they will help in future projects, shape the school prestige in the eyes of society, region and Lithuania. project duration 12 months.

Practical training  helps to prepare future specialists for practical activities  and provides competence, knowledge and skills which are used in real work places. Skills which would help quick and successful adaptation and integration into labour market. 
Good theroretical knowledge and practical skills influences successful work of a cook.
It is important for a cook to know technologies of meals preparation, how to determine food quality using visual and sensual methods. They have to know equipment for food preparation, cooking machines,  how to work with freezing equipment, measuring utencils, using suitable dishes, hygiene requirements. Creativity, quick orientation, organizational skills, team work skills, foreign languages abilities, sociocultural  skills also are  very important for highly qualified cook.  
Participants of the project- 40 pupils in iniatial vocational training, studying cook speciality at Klaipėda Tourism school, Kretinga technological and business  school and Tauragė vocational center. Participants are studying after a basic school in vocational schools, they get secondary education and acquire profession. Future cooks will have 4 week placements in restaurants  in Germany, Italy, Unitied Kingdom, Spain.
Aims of the project are: to improve and deepen practical skills of cook‘s speciality. During placement participants will work and use practically  modern kitchen equipment, food preparation technologies, will be introduced with „Slow Food“  peculiarities,  learn how to cook such  meals. Participants  will adapt new practical and theoretical knowledge, information, material, new skills while working in practical training at schools and preparing for final exams and employment.
Participants will collect material, visual aids, reports  and will give to their teachers trainers. Teachers will discuss about possibilities of implementation new things  into practical training. It will be decided what „Slow Food“ methods should be introduced to other students, how to improve theoretical and practical modules, using the best practice of foreign partners.
Results of the project: pupils will implement placement abroad, improve their practical skills, work, get introduced to "Slow Food“ peculiarities  and different food preparation methods, cuisines, promote the attractiveness of chosen profession. It would help to become highly qualified specialists for participants.
Project would help to enrich modules, teaching programme  at Klaipėda Tourism school, Kretinga technological and business school and Tauragė professional training center. It would provoke attractivenes of cook‘s profession, better preparation for real work and  would increase motivation of pupils.
Project duration 12 months.
Small Business Clubs for socially fragile target groups

The project: "Small Business Clubs for socially fragile target groups" as the European Development Plan of the AdMERITUM Foundation for 2018-2019, is part of our organization's activity - mentoring, educational staff of the foundation, mentoring program for leaders - so-called "Leaders of change", cooperating with the foundation of volunteers from all over Poland. Leaders conduct educational activities in the form of "Small Business Clubs" in the field of entrepreneurship for local communities of entrepreneurs and future entrepreneurs, including people with motor and mental disabilities, so-called NEETs - people permanently unemployed, not participating in training and education, migrants, both immigrants from outside the EU and migrants within the EU, as well as elderly people aged 50+, as well as women from small villages. Educational activities are designed to encourage participants (target group) to enter into life on the path of entrepreneurship, which will allow to overcome the impasse in which they found themselves in their personal and professional life (these two spheres overlap and affect one another).

By implementing this project, we want to improve the quality of work of leaders and mentors themselves through participation in improvement courses at foreign partners, in order to work more effectively at the local level and include the European aspect in the clubs' activities.
The quality of educational activities for the target group at the local level will be increased by the acquisition and increasing by the educators (project participants) of the competences identified as necessary to improve, in the areas of:
- developing leadership skills in relation to educational work with a vulnerable target group of people at risk of exclusion from the community due to unemployment, inactivity, age, social status (women in small village communities)
- development conflict management skills in educational work with the target group
- increasing ICT skills to integrate the ICT tool into the educational process in working with the target group.

The quality of educational activities for the target group at the European level will be made possible thanks to the improvement of English language skills by the educators (project participants) and will be introduced thanks to establishing partnerships with partner institutions in this project, from which the educators will learn, drawing on their know-how and experience in educational work with similar target groups. Establishing partnerships will also allow the introduction of entrepreneurship education for the target group through the exchange of knowledge and experience at the European level - to organize international meetings of club participants to establish contacts, exchange knowledge and good practices.
Another area of internationalization of activities that will be possible to develop thanks to this project will be
organizing job shadowing and study visits for educators from other countries interested in establishing cooperation and implementing similar practices in their countries.
Darbas su mokiniais iš rizikos šeimų

Schools continuously seek the quality of education to help their students to establish themselves in labour market. Constant attention is paid to teach new technologies and promote self-realisation of students.  The examination of problematic children indicated an array of factors influencing their behavior: family, school, economic reasons (emigration of parents, poverty),the inner values, peer subculture, personal qualities (character), influence of the media.Scientists describe the disadvantaged children as children, who do not go to school, have behavioral problems at school, abuse alcohol and psychotropic substances, tend to engage in criminal activities, are at risk of psychological, physical or sexual abuse or violence in the family and their ability to develop and participate in public life is limited. Studies show that these children cannot use their abilities in decent ways, do not participate in social life, do not trust themselves (so they quickly take offense for a teacher’s or peer’s notes), lack social skills, their interests are narrow. They often have psychological difficulties in learning and behavior but can quickly  respond to changes. They are quite well targeted, can react to changes, but they find it difficult to take over the values, because their life experience does not rely on them.In consortium partner schools a number of students come to learn from disadvantaged families where parents cannot properly care for the children because of  lack of social skills or use state support not for family needs, so there is a risk for child’s mental, physical, spiritual and moral development and security.Schools try to cooperate with families, social welfare institutions and help these children. As the survey was taken with partner schools, there are more and more such children coming to schools. There are many challenges facing teachers who first need to solve their psychological, social and personal problems and only later do their direct job-help to learn and teach. Therefore, the project is given for the teachers to visit schools in other countries and have insights about ways and methods to work with the family and to aid students, meet specialists working in institutions. Teachers need not only pedagogical and psychological knowledge, but constantly upgrade the competencies that will be required in the future to better meet the needs of these pupils and help them integrate and adapt in educational and social environment.This corresponds to Klaipeda Tourism School and the partners’ strategic plans to improve the quality and effectiveness of vocational training.It is important while learning at a vocational school to gain not only theoretical but also practical knowledge that after completion of their studies, students could more easily adapt to the labour market.Members of the project are trainers from Klaipeda Tourism, Daugai Technology and Business, Klaipeda Dressmaking and Service Business Schools, Taurage Vocational Training Centre and their authorities, planning educational process. Students get skills and abilities during educational process at school. In order to provide quality education for students in line with labor market needs, it is important that their trainers are competent. During the project, 32 participants, trainers, administrators, would jointly monitor the organization of training in vocational schools in Germany, England, Spain and Italy.Results: Participants will update the pedagogical and psychological knowledge, will improve teaching methods, methods of work with students from disadvantaged families in 4 sending schools.Teachers will go to monitoring visits, exchange the experience and after returning will prepare presentations, discuss with the authorities, social educators and psychologists what methods can be applied in schools according to their institutional needs. Impact on schools: Better quality of vocational training and students' preparation; better quality of training programs, increasing the attractiveness and improvement of the image of schools; the positive impact on teaching staff, improving their competencies; better adaptability of vocational education to labor market requirements; improved cooperation with the social partners in Lithuania and abroad;Impact on pupils: Easily accessible and career-oriented vocational training; competitiveness of acquired specialties in Lithuania and international markets; designed training (learning) environment, based on human values; established interesting and rich socio-cultural environment.Impact on teachers: Created the right conditions to reveal the professionalism, improved competences of trainers and authorities; implemented motivation to promote self-esteem and its strengthening activities, enabling to feel competitive in Lithuanian labor market, increased teachers’ and authori; implemented motivation to promote self-esteem and its strengthening activities, enabling to feel competitive.
Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational education VI

In our project are trainees of several programmes included. There are trainees, who are educated full time in school, we call them "Assistenten", the name of this kind of education programme is Höhere Berufsfachschule (HBFS), within this programme we have four emphases, these are Chemical technology (Chemical technicians), Biological technology (Biological technicians), Media design and information technology.
Additionally to the full time in school educated trainees we include trainees (mostly Biological Lab Assistants) out of the so called dual system.
The main topic of the project "Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational training VI" is to provide opportunities to our trainees, who come almost out of the rural surroundings of our school, to make vocational experiences abroad in Europe.
We think that the young generation of the current trainees at the time of globalisation won't be able to stay for their whole professional life at home near their place of birth or their place of youth. They will have to be ready to join companies abroad, if they want to be successful in their jobs. In Sweden, as well as in the other countries where we are looking for options for internships, the trainees will meet foreign working cultures, which will not be common to them. They will learn to be a stranger the hard way, during their four week placements. We think this will help to develop broad-mindedness and acceptance for foreign people and cultures within their companies and living environment at home in the rural area of Marburg. Hopefully they will educate their fellow pupils in this way, when they are back from the four week internships.
The coaching of the students abroad will force us teachers as well. Our foreign language competences, especially our skills in using the technical language will increase by the communication with the instructors in the companies abroad. This will have positive effects not only to us but also to the pupils, who were not brave enough so far to do an internship abroad.

Young people EVS 7 is an Erasmus + European Voluntary Service project. Malta, Portugal and Italy. The project application was prepared by the Turkish National Agency according to the coordinator organization.

The real aim in realizing this project is to bring together our young people with our volunteers living abroad, mainly in Europe, that we are disadvantaged in time and economically in our university, and it is unwise to have the idea of global citizenship to be peaceful individuals. For this reason, we refer to volunteers and students as a volunteer for EVH to send abroad as EVS volunteers and to help our students learn, learn and improve skills or acquire new skills.

In our project, in summary; For 30 volunteers, direct the activity site for 30 short periods.
Malta; Between 01-06-2018 / 24-10-2018, there are a total of 10 volunteers, two short term 2 month term volunteers,
Portugal; Between 01-06-2018 / 24-10-2018, there are a total of 10 volunteers, two short term 2 month term volunteers,
Italy; 01-06-2018 / 24-10-2018 We have 2 volunteers in total for 2 short-term months and 10 volunteers in total.

Our main goals and main focuses in these activities are as follows.
- Raising awareness of Europe among the peoples
- To enable young people to acquire new knowledge, skills and experience
-Improving quality in youth work
-To contribute to the acquisition of new experiences by other organizations
- To offer active participation opportunities for young people with limited education
I know more about our sickness and make mine more
-The ones who are trying to create value for my grandmother are planned to gain everything.

In our project, volunteers will receive assistants to the qualification staff and actively participate in the development of the professional development program. The selection of the volunteers will be made by consultation with the relevant staff. Volunteers can plan their own activities if they wish, and creative ideas are welcomed and made by all partners. They will receive volunteer language training in the project. Language training is a practical speech conversation everyday. Volunteering times were arranged together with the host organizations. The host organizations will primarily see the motivation letters of the volunteers and then decide. It is your responsibility to volunteer at the criteria required by the sending organization's host organization.

The target mass of the projects is generally disadvantaged youth, and at the end of the project, these young people are planning to improve themselves and culturally develop their employability. Projects aiming at international mobility and social awareness in the short term, fold in the floor in the participation of youth.

The project is based on European Council calling on EU members in 2012 as well as Bruges Communication. It is necessary to increase the number of trainees and apprentice and encourage co-operation between vocational schools and employers, integrate training programmes (where possible), make work-based learning more effective. The Cedefop research shows that these factors have a positive effect on youth employment and economic competitiveness. 
Work-based learning is extremely popular in many European countries. It has long-lived traditions and has justified itself. Practical training takes place in real workplace whereas training establishment provides students with new particular theoretical knowledge. This learning process helps an employee to acquire all the necessary competences for a specific job. 
This form of learning has been recently put into practice in Lithuania. Thus, it is believed the project will help to gain experience from foreign partners and learn how to organize student training in real workplace. Employers suggest introducing new technologies to students during learning process and, if possible, teaching them how to work with specific computer programmes.  
These items have been reflected in the strategic plans of Klaipeda Tourism School and Vilnius Tourism and Trade School. The goal is to improve the quality and effectiveness of educational teaching as well as develop co-operation with social partners, i.e. companies, in Lithuania and abroad. 
The official statistics and employment agencies state that essential problem in today‘s labour market is lack of right professionals. Because of the situation employers are looking for potential employees who seek to acquire a profession. It is important for students to acquire both theoretical and practical knowledge so that they could easily adapt to conditions in labour market and be able to apply acquired theoretical knowledge effectively. 
Students gain their abilities and skills at school and companies during their practical training. The teachers preparing these students need to be highly competent in order to provide them with high quality education correspondent to the needs of labour market. Professional training teachers have to constantly improve their technology competencies  both in Lithuania and foreign companies involved in hospitality business. 
Another important aspect is establishment of sectoral practical training centres.
Participants of the project are vocational education teachers teaching at Klaipeda Tourism and Vilnius Tourism and Trade Schools. The teachers are reponsible for educating future professionals involved in  catering, trading, management and tourism business. Oher participants are administration representatives who plan teaching process, and social partners from joint stock company ‚Biskvitas‘ and Amberton Klaipeda Hotel. 
32 participants, among them vocational education teachers and employers‘ representatives, would be able to observe the organization of work-based teaching in Germany, England, Spain, Italy. The countries have been chosen for their success in implementing dual, apprenticeship-based teaching in companies for many decades. The participants would also visit vocational schools. Having implemented this project, the present methods of school-based and  work-based practical training would have been improved.

The project  is planned within 1 action, ie. A1. Participation in courses / training. The project participants will take part in a 5-day course-  "CLIL For Primary School Teachers". CLIL - relates to an integrated content and language learning based on the simultaneous transmission of content areas and elements of the subjects taught in a  foreign language. CLIL method is recommended by the European Commission to promote language learning and linguistic diversity. This is a linguistic-methodical course, focused on the needs of participants in the English language and subjects taught.Partner of the project - Language Link,  training institution in London, accredited by the British Council as a member  Englich Teaching Center in  the UK. The partner  is recognized by Cambridge ESOL.The project  will be attended by 30 teachers divided into 3 groups. They will leave for training on the following dates:First group of teachers - 3 early childhood education, 1environmeny, 1 historian, 1 music, 1 physical education, English-  3, January 2017.The second group of techers- 4 early childhood education, 1advisor, 1 educator, 2 English, 1 history, 1 mathematics,  April 2017.The third group of teachers-  4 early childhood education,  1 advisor 1 mathematics, 3 Polish, 1  English, July 2017Aim of the project:Acquiring the ability to use English in teaching for 30 teachers of different subjects in order to exchange experiences in the field of teaching methodology within different subjects - 12 months.The specific objectives of the project:1.Raising the quality of student learning through the use of experience gained.2. Acquisition by the school teachers the knowledge, skills and experience in the field of cultural education in order to assist their students3. Identification of European values and increase of European awareness.4. The opening of the school to the new methodological solutions by sharing experiences and comparing education systems in European schools.5. Establishing cooperation with schools from the EU.

The aim of the project “London-Nantes: Channelling Business” is to enable Ursulinen Mechelen 1 pupils studying Business Support and Office Assistance to do internships in London or Nantes respectively.

An internship abroad allows pupils to apply their knowledge, skills and attitudes in a “real life” context. They use their specialized knowledge and skills in a realistic context and also fine-tune attitudes such as punctuality, politeness, appropriate manners, flexibility, tenacity. Meanwhile, they are immersed in the culture of their city in the broadest sense of the word: highlights, cultural differences, corporate culture, mentality, language, cuisine, etcetera. In this way, our pupils will become European citizens and gain an invaluable asset towards their continuing education or further career.

Business Support pupils have the opportunity to do an intense two week internship in London. We want to fully expose our pupils to the life of the metropolis and British (corporate) culture. We have chosen London for its specific nature: pupils will use Transport for London to commute to their internships, they will stay in host families, they can enjoy a West End show, have English breakfast, explore culture highlights, use the pound sterling, experience left-hand traffic - things which are not immediately apparent for our vocational pupils but which are all the more enriching. The project attains a number of objectives which are part of the curriculum, not only for the internship but also for subjects such as English and Integrated Common Subjects (PAV), as well as cross-curricular attainment targets (VOET’en).

Office Assistance pupils in their turn will have the opportunity to do an internship in France. The city of Nantes is an obvious choice: it is a vibrant, trendy port city with a flourishing commercial sector. Our pupils exchange the familiar comfort of their home environment for a true change of scenery. Alongside the obvious and often necessary immersion in French language and culture, pupils are introduced to the unique character of French business and company culture. They can carry out administrative tasks in a realistic context and are given the chance to apply curriculum objectives regarding intercultural competencies such as the rules of etiquette in their daily interactions (greeting, parting, apologising, thanking, inviting, telephoning), whether in formal or informal, oral or written communication (personal letters, mails, social networks).
