From the applied contingent of places are 249 for students all over Germany (Pool project). All given standards of the the PP are implemented within our project.
Project background:
During the last few years we have been able to offer the project throughout the entire country and to raise the number of flows (phase from 1.6.2015 - 31.5.2017 so far about 200). At the same time, we have been able to involve more training companies and vocational schools (industrial and business).
Project goals:
Our project aims specifically at enhancing applicants’ job chances through their acquisition of a further qualification. With this main goal, we are confident that participants – in addition to strengthening their self-competence - will improve their communication skills in a foreign language and will absorb new learning methods (informal and non-formal learning) thus strengthening and broadening their overall professional and political competencies. The intention of our project is to enable applicants to participate in the Erasmus+ Programme who otherwise have no such opportunity through a school or an company
Number and profiles of participants:
We have applied for 289 flows for the coming application period, the majority of which for a period of four or more weeks. Most of the participants are in a dual vocational system. Twenty of these applicants are completing their vocational education (horticulture, agriculture and home economics) in a facility for the handicapped and have special needs.
Description of project activities:
The project coordinator carries the main responsibility for preparation, operative implementation and evaluation. Specialised institutions and experts are involved when preparatory seminars are carried out. Language courses are in some instances organized by the participants themselves or – where eligible for funding – are carried out in the respective training companies or schools. These make a preselection of the applicants based on qualitative criteria. We make the final decision on the choice of the participating students.  Our policy is to leave organising accommodation in the target country and making travel arrangements to the participants themselves. We merely assume an advisory and supportive role. Schools and the training companies are involved in the wrap-up.
Procedures for project realisation:
All of the participants are required to submit applications to us (motivation essay, CV etc.) and to take part in our preparatory seminars (general information about the project, EU management game). All applicants receive our brochure with detailed information about the programme. As needed, we assist in the search for partner companies. The preparatory seminars take place at various locations, depending of the participants. Those travelling alone are given individual support. During their stay, participants must prepare a weekly report which has to be sent to the project coordinator the following week by e-mail. There is a total of three evaluation questionnaires that must be completed.
Description of the targeted results and impact
The main goal of our programme is to enhance applicants’ job chances through a further training qualification, which also empowers them to be tolerant and open when dealing with people from other countries as well as to be able to live and work in other countries. We are confident that these main goals will be reflected in broadened political competence in addition to the professional competencies gained. We support workers’ councils in their task of improving the quality of vocational training and to disseminate Erasmus+.
Description of the anticipated long-term benefits 
For training companies, sending trainees on internships is an integral part of personnel development. Through the stays in a foreign country, participants gain an important broadening of their competencies which greatly enhances their employment chances. (The majority of the flows are for four weeks or longer.)  Participants with special needs gain increased independence. Through these transfer activities/mobility measures, our organisation is able to deepen and broaden its competencies and is in a position to implement other European programmes also involved with the first steps in vocational training. The publicity-effective functions at which, together with the Information Centre Europe Direct, we award Europass Mobility, contribute to better public awareness of the European unification.
European College of Business and Management

SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL are mobility programme for trainees. The programmes are being conducted by sequa and commenced operation in September 2008. SINDBAD is an European Mobility Programme for trainees; TRANSDUAL is a Mobility Programmes for trainees who intend to untertake practical and theoretical learning either in Madrid, Paris or London. Soft skills like mobility, flexibility, tolerance and capacity for teamwork become increasingly important in the labour markets. The programmes' targets are to supporting the development of these soft skills. SINDBAD and TRANDUAL targets are to gain professional experience on international level. SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL are being funded by the LEONARDO DA VINCI programme. LEONARDO DA VINCI, itself, is the non-academic mobility programme within the LIFE LONG LEARNING Programme (LLP) of the European Commission. sequa´s  role is to file the application and to administrate the funds. 

484 mobility flows shall be implemented in the project period 2014 - 2016.



Mobility of Vocational & Educational Institutions and Trainers (move-it) is sequa’s mobility programme dedicated to the vocational education and training professionals. Since June 2012 the programme is conducted by sequa in cooperaton with partner organisations. move-it is financed by "VETPRO - Vocational Education and Training Professionals", a sub-programme of the European Commission’s Leonardo-da-Vinci programme. 

108 mobility flows shall be implemented in the project period 2014- 2016.



Both mobility programmes are “pool projects” and the respective flows for participants are published nationwide and accessible for anyone who fulfills the application criteria. Thereby individuals whose trade training institution has not applied for mobility projects do also have the possibility to participate in the EU Erasmus+ programme
European College of Business and Management

sequa is a non-profit organization of the German private sector. Shareholders are Germany's top four business membership organisations DIHK, ZDH, BDI and BDA as well as GIZ. sequa is a globally operating development organisation that has carried out projects and programmes of international cooperation in close collaboration with the German private sector since 1991. VET and mobility of employees is one of the organisation’s main purposes and thus has always been of special significance. From 1991 to 2015 sequa has carried out more than 2,000 mobility measures for apprentices, journeymen and professionals in TVET sector. The commitment of sequa in the field of occupational mobility began in 1991 with the founding of the SESAM program for journeymen, which was initially restricted to the cooperation between German and French Chambers of Crafts. Going abroad allowed the participants to learn new techniques within their occupations in the host country and increased their language skills and intercultural competences. The funding opportunities of the EU Leonardo da Vinci programme, now Erasmus+, allowed the extension of the programmes and lead in 2008 to the establishment of the sequa mobility programmes SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL. TRANSDUAL aims at trainees in commercial occupations and supports business language and skills training in France, the UK and Spain. The programme SINDBAD involves apprentices of all professions with internships throughout Europe. Additionally sequa offers since 2012 mobility’s for professionals in Vocational Education. The programme move-it (mobility of vocational educational institutions and trainers) enables individual professionals in Vocational Education to exchange work experiences and techniques with other professionals abroad. These professionals in Vocational Education are important multipliers in mobility. Teachers and trainers can use their learning experiences abroad to create networks, engage closer to the private sector and motivate their apprentices as to mobility issues. This contributes to the intra-European recognition of learning experiences and supports the harmonization of European TVET systems.
European College of Business and Management

As the European mobility and the acquisition of transversal key competences during the vocational training are of high relevance, we want to extend the services of the Erasmus+ pool project EuroMobility and increase our contribute to the European networking. Many apprentices have shown their interest in undertaking an internship abroad. But they need appropriate support and guidance, especially as an own application to a mobility project is an obstacle for them and their companies. 
With this application we plan to enable a stay abroad for 90 apprentices, mainly from SMEs, within the next two years. The planned industry focuses of the project includ the areas of electrical, metal/ engine- and vehicle construction, services [esp. Hotel / catering, cleaning], logistics, business / management [esp. in the field of wholesale and foreign trade, retail, office] and care / health. These industries benefit especially from the European Economic Area and have concrete prospects of integration because of the impending shortage of skilled workers. The apprentices and their companies will be supported by qualified BWHW professionals. The apprentices can be sent individually for a four to six week internship in suitable foreign partner companies in order to gather new practical experiences, additional job related qualifications and personal as well as professional key skills. During that time the trainees should learn traditional work processes and develop their own mobility in the European job market as well. The planned stay abroad is an integral part of the vocational training. The work plan abroad is based upon the current occupation and is coordinated in advance with the training company, the vocational school and the relevant authorities. 
The BWHW offer a linguistic, educational, professional and intercultural preparation and with the current partners abroad will provide a full support and supervision for every step of the mobility.  Partners in countries such as France, Italy, Poland, Ireland, Spain and Great Britain are provided. The partners abroad are companies and business-related institutions, which will be able to provide suitable internship positions. Depending on demands new partners will be added to the pool.
Auszubildende und Lehrer aus Bremen Erkunden Europa
European College of Business and Management

Our Internationalisation Concept is focussed on providing language and intercultural training for competent specialists with the option of obtaining further qualifications to enhance their mobility. At the heart of the development process towards achieving these declared aims lie the structuring and execution of additional international mobility projects.

Our three-week Business Communication Competence project in London has a number of core elements – acquiring intercultural competence through pertinent language seminars, the completion and presentation of a team project highlighting professional language fluency. It concludes with a certificate of proficiency graded according to the Common European Framework of Reference and will be offered in this form in future. In addition, it serves as a basis for the planning and execution of projects with an alternative concept: two-week placements in cooperation with tried and new partners with the objective of exchanging views and experience of professional practice through company visits and discussion with all of those involved in vocational training. Furthermore, relevant topics can be included flexibly, e.g. current developments in the EU.

Our contact to Lycée Pierre de Coubertin, Calais, will be reactivated. Rather than the previous three-week twinning with the emphasis on work placement, the future emphasis will be on small groups interacting and discussing. For trainees and teaching staff alike this should enable an international exchange of outlooks – not necessarily in English alone. Sitting in on lessons, company visits as well as extramural activities provide for enhanced intercultural competence and the opportunity for didactic reflection and development.

The relationship with Omnia, in Espoo, Finland, should develop along similar lines, whereby English will be paramount. By bringing together compatible professional sectors, greater emphasis will be placed on topics specifically related to the sector in question.

Our new partnership with LSE in Liverpool provides two further offers meeting our aspirations: for our apprentices language development is the primary objective flanked by company visits with groups formed more on the basis of the level of fluency rather than their training focus. As our English department expands and is strengthened through the Vocational College English Qualification at the Oldenburg Further Education Centre, Liverpool runs a particularly apposite intensive course culminating in the Cambridge Teaching Knowledge Test (TKT). Participants not only consolidate specific vocabulary, but also through teaching their main subject to the Liverpool study group explore, expand and develop didactic approaches. A parallel course offered by the established International Study Programme gives us even greater flexibility to enable our staff to acquire further qualifications.

Hitherto we have offered our apprentices the professional KMK English Language certificate at Level B2. The successful initiation of the Europakaufmann qualification in cooperation with five other internationally engaged Bremen vocational colleges has attracted 47 participants in 2017. Along with concentration on the theme of International Commerce, the English KMK Certificate Level B1, qualification in a further foreign language at minimum Level A1 and the ECDL, a three-week work placement abroad with intercultural interaction is also required. For this we have the partners Liverpool and ECBM with their great experience. The europass will be issued for this.

Sending staff to support participants has definitely enhanced the success and quality of our Mobility projects to date and further strengthened the Internationalisation awareness of accompanying staff. Our expanding concept for Mobility involves intensifying the participation of staff in project activities. They will have the added opportunity for comparing international approaches to vocational training and an exchange on didactics with their opposite numbers in vocational institutions. The ensuing reflection and multiplication of their experiences in various locations will promote the internationalisation of our college.
Spedition, Großhandel, Industrie, Büromanagement in Europa
European College of Business and Management

1st flow: 19.05.19 - 08.06.19
2nd flow: 10.05.20 - 30.05.20
   b,  Aim of the project:
        Participants are expected to improve their professional, linguistic, cultural skills.

In the ongoing year the financial European support has already been granted till 2019. The flow will take place for the 5th time.

It will take place in the "European College of Business & Management" in London and will last for a week A visit is planned to the MidKent College in Kent and we hope that the colleagues can study  the vocational educational  training and apprenticeship of our neighbour country and ameliorate the knowledge about GB. They should also imprive their linguistic competences and get new ideas for didactic methods. We would like to repeat and implement this program and so we apply again for funding to do another flow in the academic year 2019/2020. For the oncoming year we are planning new projects:

5.We will go to Northern Ireland to Derry with 16 of our colleagues and we will visit the NorthWest Regional Col. in Derry. We hope that there will develop an exchange programme done with techers as lond as this will be possible under the white elephant of Brexit. Northernirish colleagues are kindly invited to come to our school and also visit companies in our area to get to know and learn more about our dual system.

6. However, we also intend to create a new program for students of our office management department. They should attend school there as well as attending companies to see and to get to know different styles of vocational learning. We do apply for 2 flows - 1 in each year - for a number of 10 students each year. Up to now office management has always been a group which did not participate in any European programs and we would like to change this and integrate them as well and offer them possibilities to experience other cultures and get to know other traditions. 7. We were lucky to find another new partner in the Netherlands in Alkmaar, the Horizon College. 9 teachers, 7 from our college BS4 and 2 from our neighbouring college 5 are going to Alkmaar in October to prepare a students´programme together with our partner colleagues. However, times have changed in favour of us and more and more enterprises seem to support a three weeks stay abroad. Up to now we were lucky to win and add new partnerships and we experienced a high amount of support in doing this. We have started EU-mobility programs six years ago and are developping slowly into a sort of hub and we will involve other vocational colleges in the region  via our own programs  or by giving them advise how to launch new European mobility programs

The  “Berufskolleg Suedstadt“ in Cologne offers full-time or part-time training programmes to its trainees. Being one of the first European schools in North Rhine-Westphalia, it has always been aiming at enabling all its students the realization of an internship in other European countries. The educational programme “State-certified Commercial Assistants with Focus on Foreign Languages” had been acting as forerunner and was, thus, able to establish contacts and partnerships with business enterprises and schools in France, Great Britain, Spain, Malta and Cyprus in the past decades which every year provide placements to the applicants. This year, 41 trainees will realize an internship in the countries mentioned above as well as in Poland and Ireland. The internship lasting 8 or 11 weeks, respectively, serves as the practical application of the theoretically acquired knowledge during the vocational training. It takes place in its last year when students already have acquired very good knowledge in foreign languages and MS Office. The participants of the internship project carry out commercial correspondence, translate texts into the German language, create customers’ files, participate in customer acquisition, verify transport documents and carry out tasks of the front or back office in hotels. Five interns of the course of “Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks” will realise their 3-weeks-internship in Great Britain  towards the end of their second year of traineeship. For these students there also exists a pool of partner companies which annually take new interns or help them to find a placement in order to apply and broaden their language skills. Moreover, the internships serve to gain new insights into the practical work of an enterprise. As a consequence, the participants support the employees when doing their daily work and – depending on the respective branch – carry out tasks like the re-organisation of a clients’ file, the research of information about topics communicated beforehand or the assistance in an event’s organisation. 
Furthermore, this year 10 trainees of the vocational courses “Individual Insurance”, “Retailers” and “Personnel Service Providers” will do their 3-weeks-internship in European countries, frequently in subsidiaries of their employing company, where they are offered the opportunity to work quite goal-oriented taking into account probable cultural differences. For the first time, two students of the educational programme called “Commercial College” are aiming at a 2-weeks-internship abroad. Within the framework of the college’s strategy of internationalisation, it is planned to establish a pool of partner enterprises, too, in order to offer the possibility of taking part in the internship programme to even more students than those of the courses mentioned above. Without the financial support and the formal framework of the ERASMUS+, students of any of the college’s educational programmes could hardly realise an internship abroad. All participants firstly apply in writing for a scholarship with the respective colleague in charge. “Berufskolleg Suedstadt” has got an EU-Team which is led by a project coordinator. Two other colleagues are responsible for the financial processing and insurance matters. Additionally, in each educational programme there is a colleague who is familiar with its specific circumstances and supervises the trainees. Due to the high number of interns deriving from the “Assistants with Focus on Foreign Languages”, there is a colleague responsible for English-speaking EU-countries, Spain and France each, whereas singular internships in Poland this year and the like are cared for by the project coordinator. Once a general overview of the internship programme has been provided by the project coordinator, the teachers in charge draw a selection of the participants, prepare the internship itself, care for the students during their stay abroad and monitor the follow-up work after their return. This also comprises an intensive maintenance of the contact with partner institutions. Due to the possibility of job-shadowing, the personal mobilities in France, Great Britain and Malta predominantly serve the upgrading and broadening of content aspects, especially in foreign trade, customer communication and development of the vocational education in various European countries. Moreover, language skills are intensified and – if necessary – improved. The personal maintenance of the contacts with partnership firms enabled by these mobilities, is a vital factor of the project’s success and must not be underestimated. In order to take part in a personal mobility, the staff applies to the head of the college who - according to the qualification and demand – decides for the teacher to take part in the project. The results of the personal mobilities are communicated to the staff in team meetings, conferences of members of the same subject or educational programme and the students.
Mobile Tools and Gamification as a new Language Assessment System in Tourism
European College of Business and Management

BACKGROUND
For 15 years some of the project partners have been engaged in the fostering of the EU L2 standard for professionals in tourism. Various institutions have been supporting this initiative and a significant body of courseware has been produced and implemented in educational and training institutions. 
The first LdV-project "ESB", winner of the EU Label 2001, was followed by SLEST (www.slest-tourism.org; EU Label 2007), with which a whole two-level L2 learning courseware has been created, following the "EU Framework of Reference for Languages". From 2013 on  further L2 learning materials for the tourism sector in an e-learning format (see also www.slest2-0.eu) has been produced.  

OBJECTIVES
The project will establish an advanced mobile and gamified eLearning framework for students and professionals in the tourism sector in the form of online L2 training tools. Thus an international social network of professionals will be created, perfectly suited for improving L2 and intercultural communication competences.  
Analytics, collective diagnostics, measuring learning outcomes and gamification will be addressed in a very innovative way. Psychometrics will be embedded in the online exercises. The games produce big data about the knowledge development of the participants; this is evaluated by a psychometric software component. Participants receive a continuous feedback on their performance with personalised training tips. The trainers receive anonymized collective diagnostics, showing which knowledge is mastered, what is forgotten, and what could be sustainably strengthened over time. We will set up regular tournaments from 2018 on as a sustainable endeavor supported by major educational and vocational institutions.

PARTNERS
The project consists of 5 partners coming from Turkey, Germany, Italy, and the UK: municipality of Serik Belek (TR), an university (Selcuk-TR), two vocational institutions (UK and IT), and SNTL in DE (electronic publishing, content management systems, open source technologies, gamification). This partnership and network will guarantee  a high professional standard regarding the outcomes, and also an extensiv dissemination of project results. 

ACTIVITIES PLANNED
a) Publishing and maintaining the project website, also after the end of the funding period. The partners will make sure that  the
website contains engaging and high quality L2 learning and cross-cultural communication contents for the Tourism sector. The very special feature on the website will be the multi-player  application on which the tournaments / training sessions for professionals and students in the EU Tourism Industry will be launched.
b) Production of specific L2 e-learning contents for the online tournaments / training sessions 
c) Defining and authoring the dramaturgy of the online tournaments. Organizing the online games and training sessions as a continuing learning outcome assessment in the field of Tourism 
d) Organization of training activities on- and offline regarding b) and c)
e) Online assistance for all participants

METHODOLOGY USED
The project will apply a number of different methodologies:
- Gamification of learning and testing through the deployment of knowledge competitions in social networks with embedded psychometrics
- Self-organised learning with personalised learning tips and references based on analytics
- Learning in social networks through multi-playing 
- Intercultural learning through cross-border social gaming 
- online social interaction in the learning games 
- Ubiquitous learning through mobile access to gaming and learning contents

RESULTS/ IMPACT ENVISAGED
- A comprehensive L2 programme for the Tourism Sector using a gamified learning and testing methodology with knowledge competitions  
- Creation of a framework for regular L2-knowledge competitions financed by industry and other stakeholders
- The online tournaments become a landmark for innovative learning methodologies and will be taken up by other institutions 
- Learning analytics will give high visibility 
- Authors and publishers will be encouraged to further develope gamification of education and training. 

LONG TERM BENEFITS
We will establish an eLearning framework in the form of regular knowledge competitions. Users will have the opportunity to improve skills in L2 and cross-cultural communication wherever and whenever they want, with or without the help of teachers/ trainers, also beyond  the funding period of this project.
The gaming environment will remain active; knowledge tournaments will be organized regularly in all countries of the project; learning contents on the project’s website maintained regularly. The project thus will create a critical mass on contents, materials, organisational infrastructure and visibility and publicity that it approaches, methodologies and concepts will produce a high degree of acceptance and permeate successfully the educational, vocational and human resources sector.
Kaufmännische Auszubildende in England und Estland
European College of Business and Management

The Kaufmännische Schulen 1 Villingen-Schwenningen (KS1), Kaufmännische Schulen Göppingen (KSGÖ) and Kaufmännische Schulen Offenburg (KSOG) would like to enable young apprentices to get work experience abroad as part of their dual training (e.g. as industrial clerks or financial assistants). The aim of this is an increased intercultural and personal competence to help master new challenges in business as well as personal life. Businesses, which are very often internationally orientated, would thus benefit from highly motivated employees who would be more self-assured in their treatment of foreign customers and suppliers. Participation in the project can also lead to enhanced willingness to work abroad inside the EU.
The project is aimed at students with university entry qualification and those entitled to study at specialist colleges and universities of applied sciences, whose level of proficiency in English is at least B2 (for Great Britain), and good students who graduated from middle school with a sound knowledge of English, which they can use to bridge communication gaps (for Estonia). The participants will be apprentices of various different professions in their second year of training. The focus will be on bank clerks, industrial clerks as well as clerks in administration, but the project will be open to all other professions, like office clerks and automotive clerks. At the time of departure, students in three-year courses will have passed about one half of their training, those in two-year courses (e.g. financial assistants) will have passed about two-thirds of their training. This will guarantee that they have sufficient qualification, competence and profound basic knowledge of economics to benefit from the internships and other offers that are part of the project.

In Great Britain, the focus of the project is on obtaining the “office worker international – AHK” qualification of the German-British Chamber of Commerce.
In Estonia, the project focuses on “seeing beyond the end of one’s nose”.
In both countries, participants are supposed to strengthen their key qualifications – teamwork, problem solving, testing self-organised procedures. In Estonia, special emphasis will be on doing an internship, forming ties in the twinning schools and finding one’s way on new terrain.
In the course of two years, 80 apprentices are to be sent to Great Britain, and 12 to Estonia.
All partners in the project have been in contact for a number of years, and procedures and coordination before and during the stays are will-known, tried and tested. Dates for the stays have already been appointed, same as the coordination of course contents. In Great Britain, the ECBM course includes English Business Communication, excursions to the Docklands and an oral exam as well as a written essay exam. In Estonia, the agenda includes participating in classes at the two business colleges, a one-week internship, a visit to the German Embassy as well as guided tours of Tallinn, Riga and Helsinki, which will be prepared by the participants themselves.

To sum up, the project is meant to render the participating students highly independent in planning and organising their own learning situations and environment. It is a long-term goal to enhance mobility and to prepare the students for an unknown environment, as it is less and less likely for them to remain in the places where they are being trained. Intercultural competence is becoming increasingly important at school and in the workplace, with colleagues just as with customers. When dealing with them, it is of particular importance to show understanding and empathy, especially for those who come from foreign nations and cultures. Self-organisation of exchange processes is of central pedagogical importance in this project. The participants will have to let themselves in for each other, make decisions together and coordinate their decisions with those of others. Self-organisation is a crucial educational aim which is meant to enable the young people to be resourceful and to take the initiative. This will further creativity and facilitate professional development. Taking the initiative and accepting responsibility for one’s decisions are basic prerequisites for successful professional progress.
Internationaler Kaufmann - Neue Wege in der Berufsausbildung für Industriekaufleute
European College of Business and Management

We see our newly prepared course „Internationaler Kaufmann – Neue Wege in der Berufsbildung für Industriekaufleute” as integrated foreign-language training. In advance the students are trained in a plus-programme at our vocational school in terms of data processing, foreign language, sociopolitical topics and giving presentations. In a three-week course at the European College of Business and Management in London, with 26 teaching units a week, the pupils apply their knowledge by giving short talks, preparing power point presentations and writing compositions about economic and politico-economic tasks in English. In addition they have typical Business English units such as correspondence, telephoning and cultural differences. The cross-cultural competence will be improved by several excursions. The written project report (approximately 1500 words) will be completed and edited (text processing, image editing, graphics) after the stay at home. These reports will be passed on to the European College to be assessed. The students can acquire three certificates: German-British Chamber Certificate, European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the Europass.To acquire these certificates the students need to perform the following efforts:Written project report (approximately 1500 words) after the end of the course at home, a power point presentation about an economic topic, a three hour written test.We are planning to integrate the results of the mobility in the report marks and the comment of the school certificate of 11th grade. In this connection we want to check to which extent the separate achievements of the mobility can be transferred into report marks. This is what we want to develop in close cooperation with our school management, the Government of Swabia and the Ministry of Education.Absolutely essential for us is the improvement of the monitoring.We are planning:- All steps of preparation being evaluated by the students- Students take notes of their progress in a project diary- The host families being evaluated by the students- The content of the courses and the teachers of the ECBM being assessed- The professionalism of the project management of the teachers of our school being validated.In addition we want the whole project to be evaluated by the trainers of the participating KMUs.As result of the consistent further development of our project series the pupils receive the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” in cooperation with the DIHK Berlin.The requirements for this certificate, which was developed by the AHK in London, are:1. Successful conclusion of the apprenticeship to become an industrial clerk2. Successful completion of the three week mobility in London (PDP-Programme at the ECBM in London (written and oral exam plus essay))Additionally we demand at least good results in the KMK-Certificate in Business English level 2.If all qualifications are fulfilled the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” will be carried out by the ECBM in London.
Teacher Development for Professional Purposes in Vocational Education and Training
European College of Business and Management

On this project teachers from commercial schools of Bayern, Nordrhein Westfahlen, Baden-Württemberg and Hessen have the possibility to attend a professional development for business orientated English and Economics in London. The participants teach English and Economics in dual commercial business apprenticeships and other schools. The training weeks are set up as ongoing one week programmes at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM).  The target of this program is to offer an in depth and current knowledge in the area of economics, to develop specialised language skills and to allow a comparison of the apprenticeship systems. Quality management and international networking are kept in focus. The teaching materials on this development programme are available to download from our own internet page. The training staff of ECBM as well as experts from the industry and educational centers has come together to develop a specialised training programme designed with the needs of our teachers in mind. Exclusively for this programme a professional Teacher Coach has been arranged to convey modern teaching and learning methods for the principles of teaching. Furthermore the training programme will include the following themes: the British educational and apprenticeship systems, the British Justice System, current political topics (such as the EU and Britain), economic topics (such as the property market, marketing, credit crunch, Banking system in England etc.) and the construction and the implementation of teaching material.To support the theory discussed on this programme the teachers are taken to different economic institutions for example the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Bank of England, The Old Bailey, business companies etc. One special advantage for the participants is the communication between colleges on a national and international level. Through this new cooperations are planned and new networks founded. In the context with international development programmes an intercultural exchange is especially important. That is why the participants are spending the training week staying at English host families. The project enables training unimpeded by national or international borders.

Exclusively for this programme a professional Teacher Coach has been arranged to convey modern teaching and learning methods for the principles of teaching. Furthermore the training programme will include the following themes: the British educational and apprenticeship systems, the British Justice System, current political topics (such as the EU and Britain), economic topics (such as the property market, marketing, credit crunch, Banking system in England etc.) and the construction and the implementation of teaching material.

To support the theory discussed on this programme the teachers are taken to different economic institutions for example the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Metal Exchange, Bank of England, The Old Bailey, business companies etc.
 
One special advantage for the participants is the communication between colleges on a national and international level. Through this new cooperations are planned and new networks founded. In the context with international development programmes an intercultural exchange is especially important. That is why the participants are spending the training week staying at English host families. 

The project enables training unimpeded by national or international borders.
Kaufmännische Auszubildende in Estland und England
European College of Business and Management

The Kaufmännische Schulen 1 Villingen-Schwenningen (KS1), Kaufmännische Schulen Göppingen (KSGÖ) and Kaufmännische Schulen Offenburg (KSOG) would like to enable young apprentices to get work experience abroad as part of their dual training (e.g. as industrial clerks or financial assistants). The aim of this is an increased intercultural and personal competence to help master new challenges in business as well as personal life. Businesses, which are very often internationally orientated, would thus benefit from highly motivated employees who would be more self-assured in their treatment of foreign customers and suppliers. Participation in the project can also lead to enhanced willingness to work abroad inside the EU.The project is aimed at students with university entry qualification and those entitled to study at specialist colleges and universities of applied sciences, whose level of proficiency in English is at least B2 (for Great Britain), and good students who graduated from middle school with a sound knowledge of English, which they can use to bridge communication gaps (for Estonia). The participants will be apprentices of various different professions in their second year of training. The focus will be on bank clerks, industrial clerks as well as clerks in administration, but the project will be open to all other professions, like office clerks and automotive clerks. At the time of departure, students in three-year courses will have passed about one half of their training, those in two-year courses (e.g. financial assistants) will have passed about two-thirds of their training. This will guarantee that they have sufficient qualification, competence and profound basic knowledge of economics to benefit from the internships and other offers that are part of the project.In Great Britain, the focus of the project is on obtaining the “office worker international – AHK” qualification of the German-British Chamber of Commerce.In Estonia, the project focuses on “seeing beyond the end of one’s nose”.In both countries, participants are supposed to strengthen their key qualifications – teamwork, problem solving, testing self-organised procedures. In Estonia, special emphasis will be on doing an internship, forming ties in the twinning schools and finding one’s way on new terrain.In the course of two years, 80 apprentices are to be sent to Great Britain, and 12 to Estonia.All partners in the project have been in contact for a number of years, and procedures and coordination before and during the stays are will-known, tried and tested. Dates for the stays have already been appointed, same as the coordination of course contents. In Great Britain, the ECBM course includes English Business Communication, excursions to the Docklands and an oral exam as well as a written essay exam. In Estonia, the agenda includes participating in classes at the two business colleges, a one-week internship, a visit to the German Embassy as well as guided tours of Tallinn, Riga and Helsinki, which will be prepared by the participants themselves.To sum up, the project is meant to render the participating students highly independent in planning and organising their own learning situations and environment. It is a long-term goal to enhance mobility and to prepare the students for an unknown environment, as it is less and less likely for them to remain in the places where they are being trained. Intercultural competence is becoming increasingly important at school and in the workplace, with colleagues just as with customers. When dealing with them, it is of particular importance to show understanding and empathy, especially for those who come from foreign nations and cultures. Self-organisation of exchange processes is of central pedagogical importance in this project. The participants will have to let themselves in for each other, make decisions together and coordinate their decisions with those of others. Self-organisation is a crucial educational aim which is meant to enable the young people to be resourceful and to take the initiative. This will further creativity and facilitate professional development. Taking the initiative and accepting responsibility for one’s decisions are basic prerequisites for successful professional progress.
Background to British Business  / Bilaterale Entwicklung einer Wetterstation
European College of Business and Management

The two-year projects “Background to British Business” and “Bilateral Development of a Meteorological Station” aim to strengthen the quality of vocational education for teachers and pupils at the BSGZ through “work-based learning”. 
The following topics will be part of the project for educational staff and for learners:
- Learn about cross-cultural education
- Pedagogy and didactics
- International cooperation, international relations and common development

Exemplary goals 
For the organization:
- Professionalization of educational staff
- Internationalization as an important part of school development

For the learners:
- Increase of self-esteem
- Reduction of inhibitions against going abroad in a globalized world
- Development of foreign language skills

For the educational staff:
- Development of cross-cultural professional competence
- Improvement of tuition skills through experiences with foreign working methods
- Culture-sensitive handling of and empathy with learners and people with migration background
We are planning to dispatch 60 pupils from two different departments in four flows of 3 weeks each as well as six teachers of the BSGZ for one week each.

Activities for learners:
- Apprenticeship in foreign educational institutions
- Participation in classes
- Realization of a common international project
- Culture in the foreign countries
Activities for educational staff:
- Job Shadowing
- Culture in the foreign countries

The BSGZ works with ECVET instruments (e.g. Memorandum of Understanding, Learning Agreement, Europass Certificate) and ECVET principles (e.g. learning results and units of learning outcomes) to maintain the quality assurance of the projects and to promote transparency. Through ECVET we provide the recognition of the gained results and competences. The learners attend extra-curricular lessons to prepare them in every possible professional, pedagogic, intercultural and organizational way. The accompanying educational staff talk with the learners on a regular basis to monitor, reflect and discuss their professional and personal learning progress. 
Some participants are under age, so they will always be accompanied by teachers of the BSGZ.
There will be daily minutes to keep records about the learning progress. A portfolio of the stay abroad will reflect the whole experience abroad.


Project background:
English is a very important part of the curriculum for business management assistants and for industrial mechanics at vocational schools. Due to rising internationalization and globalization we see the need to qualify our students for these challenges. This is most efficient in an authentic surrounding where you can experience and acquire new skills in a direct way. Above all, trainees who have not had the opportunity of being supported, i.e. especially not through European exchange programs, should be enabled to profit from this project. This conforms to the basic principles of our school concept.
Project goals: 
The participants are expected to deepen both their general and business knowledge of English during the 3-week-course at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. With the project-related work they shall be encouraged to work on their own, improve their presentation skills as well as develop team-spirit qualifications which are essential in a modern business world. The participants in Turin work in a bilateral team.
Moreover, we want the participants to improve their language competence and gain valuable intercultural experience, build up a healthy self-confidence and develop self-worthiness not only for their professional career.
The acquired competences will be reflected by the pupils and reviewed by the teachers at the end of the project with the “Assessment of Learning Outcomes”. The experiences of the participants will also be analyzed by the BSGZ as pupils fill out an evaluation sheet after coming back from England and Italy. The Memorandum of Understanding will be reflected after every flow.
All results of the different evaluations will be used to improve future projects.
The participants share their foreign experience within the school as well as in public events in order to open up the school in an international and intercultural way. There will be reports on the project in local events with the Chamber of Commerce and the companies as well as in the press and on the website of the school.
On the long run our school will be strengthened as a modern, international and intercultural partner in the German dual system, especially for business management assistants and for industrial mechanics. Erasmus+ helps us a lot and is also an essential part of gaining that goal.
Übergang von der beruflichen Ausbildung in die Arbeitswelt
European College of Business and Management

In our two previous projects the participants compared the processes of personnel planning and personnel recruitment in Germany and in our partner countries.

Project A:
In our new project the emphasis will be on the transition from vocational training to employment and its requirements and challenges.

The students will do an internship for 3 to 4 weeks in our partner countries (Poland, Finland and Spain) and have to identify requirements that job starters have to meet, but also obstacles and challenges that both companies and job starters have to face. The students will hopefully gain new qualifications and knowledge, get prepared for the international job market but also reflect and analyse their own competences and skills.

In a second step, the participating teachers will do a job-shadowing week in our partner schools and should get an overview about the skills, competences, professional knowledge and key qualifications that are being taught during the students' vocational training. They will then compare those with the students' findings and deduce recommendations for action and good-practice-examples.

The project assignments will be as follows:
Students' project assignment: identifying typical tasks and activities of job starters, required qualifications, support measures and activities of the company (e.g. mentoring, introductory weeks, seminars) as well as obstacles and challenges. They should compare those results with their own experiences (self-reflexion).

Teachers' project assignment: identifying the skills, competences, business knowledge and key qualifications that are being taught during the students' vocational training as well as the measures to prepare the students for entering the international job market (internationalisation strategy of the school). Desirable would also be results and findings concerning the preparation for the job market of disadvantaged groups (refugees and inclusion). Since our school has started with CLIL (Content and Language Integrated Learning) lessons last September and our Spanish partner school has already been practising CLIL for several years an exchange of experiences concerning that topic is planned as well.

The results of both students and teachers will then be used to answer the following question: "In what way does the vocational training prepare the job starters for the requirements of the professional practice/the job reality?" The results will then be translated into guidelines, recommendations and good-practice-examples.

In the near future a cooperation with an Italian school is planned. Contacts with an Italian school have already been established and will be further intensified.

Project B:
Besides the mobilities of project A the school will also send 20 students per year to the European College for Business and Management in London. The students will take part in a three-week professional development programme (PDP). The business courses will be held in English and focus on international business and finance, but also Business English and international competences. After completing the PDP course the students can apply for the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC). It will be awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London), which operates under the umbrella of the German Association of Chambers of Industry and Commerce (Deutscher Industrie- und Handelskammertag, DIHK Berlin). Certificate holders prove that they are able to operate in an international business environment.

Both projects will underline and support the internationalisation of our students and will provide them with the professional and personal qualifications, skills and knowledge necessary for being able to compete on the international job market in a further together growing Europe.
European College of Business and Management

IIn Germany, vocational training is mostly provided by German enterprises in cooperation with vocational schools. We, the Staatliche Berufsschule Eichstätt, are a vocational school with more than 1,400 students. The school is located in Bavaria, Germany. As more and more small and medium-sized companies, which are our dual partners, have transnational business relations they need internationally qualified staff. 



In order to meet the requirements on local, national and international levels our school is about implementing an international strategy in our school development programme. We aim to develop the skills of our students, to increase their employability and career prospects on the European job market and to modernise our education and training. 



A first step towards this goal is our mobility project in cooperation with the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. In 2015 we want to send 40 apprentices to the United Kingdom. The apprentices are part-time students who do an apprenticeship as a management assistant in retail business, in wholesale and foreign trade or office management assistants. In order to increase their business knowledge, intercultural experience and language skills the students attend an Intensive Course (PDP - Professional Development Programmes) that takes 3 weeks. In the courses they get an overview of British business and culture and an introduction to their specific areas of occupation and interest which can be built upon at a later stage. There are also excursions that have close relevance to the course topics. Their professional competences are developed through team work, communication and and oral presentations. During their stay at  British guest families and in London they gain insights in British life and culture and  improve their cross-cultural competence and understanding. After the course the students get the European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the German-British Chamber Certificate (AHK London). Moreover, after successful completion of their final exams of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK) in Germany they can acquire the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC), which is fficially accredited by the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce (AHK) in London. 



As we want to enable and support companies and students to establish and maintain international business partnerships it is also necessary to qualify our educational staff to organize and develop European mobility programmes and partnerships and to teach our students language and intercultural skills in a modern way. Thus, we also want to send teachers to the UK to do a training assignment or work placement at the ECBM or the German-English Camber of Industry and Commerce. During their stay some of them are going to monitor and accompany our students in London. 



The use of modern teaching methods and hands-on-learning in order to prepare all participants to work successfully and confidently in an international business environment is of high importance for the whole project. 



The success and quality of the project will be monitored and assessed with different instruments, e. g.  written and oral tests, feedbacks and questionnaires. Moreover, to  validate the competences acquired by the participants during their experiences abroad all participants get the Europass Mobility Document. They use and update their Europass Curriculum Vitae (CV) and the Europass Language Passport.

Fachspezifischer Trainingskurs für kaufmännische Auszubildende in Großbritannien
European College of Business and Management

Due to the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of the working environment it has become more and more important in recent years to prepare the trainees for these challenges in their various jobs. Confident communication with foreign partners requires good knowledge in the world language English on the one hand and on the other hand also a high degree of intercultural competence. Our projects contribute to support our trainees especially in the above mentioned aspects which also corresponds to our school internal quality management understanding (“Schulinternes Qualitätsverständnis – SQV”). After having offered a language course for industrial clerk, bank clerk and office administration clerk trainees at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London for the past years we have now taken the decision to offer a practical training for retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees with B.I.G. Bristol. “Project 1” mentioned in this application form is the course at the ECBM, “Project 2” is the practical training with B.I.G. Bristol.

After getting in contact with the European College of Business and Management by the recommendation of another vocational school, various teachers of our school took part in a further education course at the ECBM. The experiences we gained there concretised the planning of an own project which was implemented the year after. Both the economic and pedagogic skills of the teachers at the ECBM concerning the transmission of central aspects of the British economy, culture and politics have convinced us to continue this project for more than ten years now.

The decision of offering another project (project 2) has prompted us to choose B.I.G. Bristol as a further partner organisation for retail clerk respectively wholesale clerk trainees. We got familiar with this company during a further education course about “Leonardo DaVinci”. B.I.G. Bristol organise practical trainings which meet the job requirements of our retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees.

The main aim of project 1 is to enable 24 students from the vocational school "Staatliche Berufsschule II Memmingen" to attend a three-weeks course at the European College of Business and Management in London. The students, who train to be a bank clerk, industrial clerk or office clerk, are all in their second year of vocational training. During the course the students are able to improve their language skills in English as well as their knowledge in business administration issues.

At the college the students attend lessons every working day between 9.30 am and 4.45 pm. The lessons deal with topics which are related to their vocational training in Germany. The lessons are held by specially trained and experienced teachers from the college. In addition to the daily lessons, the participants have to write out an assignment on a special economic or social-economic topic, which is chosen by them individually. This as well as the final presentation at the end of the course, enhances the language skills immensely.

Concerning project 2, 20 wholesale and retail clerk trainees take part in a two-week internship in various commercial companies. They will get a close insight into the job-related practical experience and get the chance to interchange with their British colleagues. 

Next to the course, the students of both projects are obliged to plan and prepare several group excursions. The group leaders decide on relevant topics and talk them over with the students during the preparation meetings. The topics are then prepared in English by the student teams, so that they can be presented by them in London respectively Bristol and the surrounding area during the group excursions. 

Another major aim of the project is to enlarge the intercultural, social and individual skills of the students. They enter a new field with unknown cultural and social requirements, they learn to communicate and to cooperate with students and teachers. Both the projects in London and Bristol focus on the strategy of internationalisation and especially concentrate on an increase of mobility of the students, teachers and employers as well as the internationalisation of the “Berufsschule II Memmingen”.

In 2017 and 2018, 34 participants of the biennial and triennial (see 1) vocational course of State-Certified Commercial Assistants for Foreign Languages, 5 participants of the so called ‘dual educational courses’ (see 2) of Personnel Service Providers, Insurers, Retailers, and 8 participants of the course of Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels will take part in the internship programme.
The Commercial Assistants who do their internship at the beginning of their last year of vocational studies then will have substantial demand of both, foreign languages in the field of commercial correspondence and terminology in foreign trade. They will have already obtained knowledge concerning such matters of commercial correspondence as enquiry, offer, order, delay in payment and notice of defects. Further, they will have learned how to handle different types of forms in the field of foreign trade and will have acquired detailed knowledge in the subjects of business administration, national economy and infonomics. In the latter they will have learned how to use computer programmes like Excel, Word and Powerpoint and will be well trained in word processing.
Due to all these skills acquired, they are qualified for working in international importing and exporting enterprises, shipping companies, international industrial concerns and organisations as well as in hotels and/or language schools.
At a time when their state of knowledge enables the trainees to deal with responsible tasks in a company or an institution, the internships offer the opportunity to link their theoretical knowledge with practical training. What concerns us primarily is that for teaching purposes didactically reduced case studies become verified in a real environment in order to enhance the students’ chances on the European labour market.
As this is a full-time vocational school training, the trainees have got few opportunities to work in side jobs to earn their own living. Thus, doing an internship in a foreign country does not only mean financial losses during the time of their stay but also considerable problems in raising the funds for a period abroad. Only if our trainees will be sponsored by the ERASMUS+ programme, we are able to realise our project which is continually carried out and supervised by qualified teachers experienced in this area.
Moreover, this programme constitutes the frame of security, trustworthiness, approval and professional advice and support which is so important to our partners and beneficiaries.
This year’s project of 8 to 11 weeks will be carried out in companies and institutions based in the UK, France, Spain, Ireland, Cyprus, Malta and Turkey. An internship of eleven weeks including the corresponding exam held and certified by a German-French board of examiners will be offered by the grammar schools Lycée St. Etienne and Lycée René-Cassin in Strasbourg.
With that the students are given the opportunity to get their practical skills certified and, thus, to obtain a more favourable starting position on the labour market. For already three years now, we have been applying the ECVET instruments in co-operation with these partners. In recurrently held workshops we regularly update and adjust the instruments to the corresponding needs.
All details described above are mainly applicable to the Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels, except the fact that these students are at the initial stage of their vocational training at the time of their internship. The trainees of the dual educational courses benefit from their three-week internship by testing their practical knowledge in other European countries. The teachers draw upon this experience by improving the quality of their training and to provide the entire staff with the newly gained knowledge and competences. 
The participants of the project will benefit considerably and sustainably, both, in their professional and private life from the improvement of their language skills, newly gained cultural insights and, last but not least, their personality development. 

1 The students of the triennial course do a combined degree course of AVCE and State-certified Commercial Assistant for Foreign Languages.
2 Dual courses are a combination of theoretical vocational training at school and practical training in a company.
