European College of Business and Management

"Mobility as a Challenge - going new ways" is a comprehensive project supporting the mobility of  learners and teachers at Walter Eucken Berufskolleg in Duesseldorf. In the next two years 42 apprentices and 28 teachers will profit from the funding. By putting a growing emphasis on teachers the WEBK is expanding its efforts in implementing the European dimension into the school's profile. Our aim is to embed our European key objectives into all our stakeholders' minds and hearts.

The project provides for different measures.
On the one hand apprentices will have the possibility to gain work experience in different European enterprises and countries, which they will organize themselves. By doing so the apprentices will explore the European labour market, will strengthen their language competence and most important of all will increase their sense of initiative / autonomy as well as their self-confidence,  all of which are decisive factors for increasing their future career chances.


On the other hand teachers will do job shadowing in Austrian and Dutch companies and schools in order to expand both their specialist knowledge and their pedagogical expertise. They will have the opportunity to exchange new ideas and concepts with colleagues from other European countries. Their increased motivation will serve as a multiplier for the whole school raising overall participation in European projects.

As a result of the careful selection of companies and educational institutions abroad teachers can improve the quality of their lessons, thereby offering our students up to date and practically oriented lessons. Furthermore, the participation and development of pan-European networks leads to an increase in knowledge on all sides, especially when transnational content is involved, e.g. logistics.

As another measure to enable more of our staff to participate in and instigate international projects the school will offer teachers to improve their language competence in English and Dutch by attending language courses.

The results of the teacher mobilities will be used to adapt and modernize learning and teaching activities, which will then be made available to all stakeholders, thereby strengthening the co-operation with our partner institutions in a sustainable way.
European College of Business and Management

In a united Europe aspects such as experiences across the continent and the knowledge of foreign languages become more and more important and evident. The Louis-Baare-Berufskolleg is a vocational college where students complete their training or obtain other educational qualifications. As a so-called "Europaschule" we account for this development.

While doing their work placements and studies as part of the project the selected students gain the above mentioned competences.  These competences cover the needs of the German economy on a global market. The selected participants provide their linguistic and technical skills to the internship company. The successful achievement of everyday work in a company as well as the process of gaining knowledge abroad strenghtens their self confidence. Moreover they learn more about different working methods and mentalities. Through this the students enhance their career prospects within the European Union. Furthermore making positive experiences beyond national borders and also making new friends in other countries reduces prejudices, stereotypes and fears.

Overall 44 students will participate in the programme. Before their stay abroad all students will be prepared for their placements and studies. This includes practical support concerning the organization locally (the booking of flights, accommodation etc.). They will either be accompanied by a teacher or supported via e-mail or telephone. In addition it is planned to visit as many of them as possible.
European College of Business and Management

General overview:

The staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen (state-owned vocational school) is planning to send a total forty German students as well as up to ten German teachers from its economics department to London for three weeks. These stays are scheduled for April 2019 and April 2020. During that time, they will be working at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM). The ECBM is the training college of the German-British Chamber of Commerce. It was founded in 1988 and is well established in the fields of basic and continuous training. They offer the "Professional Development Programme" (PDP), a 3-week intensive course, which is tailored to our students' needs. During the PDP, our students will complete and earn the certificate of “Kaufmann International (KIC)”. This certificate is awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London). This is supposed to ensure that the qualifications and skills gained abroad will improve the students' chances in the job market and that the experiences abroad will have a lasting effect. 

Selection process:

The selection process for the project will be taking place in two different ways. Students from the economics department taking part in the additional qualification "foreign language correspondence clerk" offered by the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK), will be part of the project as well as other applicants from the economics department. All participating students are obliged to hand in a letter of motivation as well as the Europass CV.
The participating teachers in the project are chosen on the basis of their willingness to take part in the project. In the long term, the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen is planning to extend the number of people involved in the project as it is one of the main objectives of the school to deepen its internationalisation strategy.

Main objectives of the project, concerning students and teachers:

Enhancing professional skills and competences:

One key objective of the project is a further qualification of the trainees of our economics department. Many of them are doing their traineeship in internationally operating companies. Therefore, they should gain job-related experience abroad as soon as possible. Getting insights into international business processes and using English as the language of business are elements that give these students a professional and personal advantage. Therefore, we are helping our students to be successful on the European labour market. 
Our teachers, taking part in the project gain insights in planning and conducting European projects and exchange skills and methods with English-speaking colleagues.

Developing personal skills and competences:

Besides, spending time abroad is helping the students to overcome fears of foreign things and helps them to gain intercultural competences. Our students live in small villages in rural Upper Bavaria. Spending three weeks in multicultural London will make a huge impression on them. Besides, working and living abroad in host families will contribute to a positive personal development. That will also help to promote tolerance and to eliminate prejudices.
Our teachers also profit from staying abroad and strengthen their insights into the European idea. Intercultural competences can only be communicated if one is convinced of the idea oneself.

Objectives of the project, concerning the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen and its partners:

The staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen wants to extend its internationalisation strategy. We want to create a network of national and international partners, from which everyone (companies, students, teacher, and our foreign partners) can profit. Even though, the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen is located in the economically very prosperous region north of Munich, which is constantly profiting from a steady influx of people, demographic change has got an impact on all institutions in vocational training. As a consequence, we see internationalisation as a chance to improve our chances as well as those of our partners in the economy to get highly motivated, productive and cosmopolitan trainees.

In 2016 and 2017, 29 participants of the biennial and triennial (see 1) vocational course of State-Certified Commercial Assistants for Foreign Languages, 10 participants of the so called ‘dual educational courses’ (see 2) of Personnel Service Providers, Insurers, Retailers, and 7 participants of the course of Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels will take part in the internship programme.The Commercial Assistants who do their internship at the beginning of their last year of vocational studies then will have substantial demand of both, foreign languages in the field of commercial correspondence and terminology in foreign trade. They will have already obtained knowledge concerning such matters of commercial correspondence as enquiry, offer, order, delay in payment and notice of defects. Further, they will have learned how to handle different types of forms in the field of foreign trade and will have acquired detailed knowledge in the subjects of business administration, national economy and infonomics. In the latter they will have learned how to use computer programmes like Excel, Word and Powerpoint and will be well trained in word processing.Due to all these skills acquired, they are qualified for working in international importing and exporting enterprises, shipping companies, international industrial concerns and organisations as well as in hotels and/or language schools.At a time when their state of knowledge enables the trainees to deal with responsible tasks in a company or an institution, the internships offer the opportunity to link their theoretical knowledge with practical training. What concerns us primarily is that for teaching purposes didactically reduced case studies become verified in a real environment in order to enhance the students’ chances on the European labour market.As this is a full-time vocational school training, the trainees have got few opportunities to work in side jobs to earn their own living. Thus, doing an internship in a foreign country does not only mean financial losses during the time of their stay but also considerable problems in raising the funds for a period abroad. Only if our trainees will be sponsored by the ERASMUS+ programme, we are able to realise our project which is continually carried out and supervised by qualified teachers experienced in this area.Moreover, this programme constitutes the frame of security, trustworthiness, approval and professional advice and support which is so important to our partners and beneficiaries.This year’s project of 8 to 11 weeks will be carried out in companies and institutions based in the UK, France, Spain, Ireland, Cyprus, Malta and Turkey. An internship of eleven weeks including the corresponding exam held and certified by a German-French board of examiners will be offered by the grammar schools Lycée St. Etienne and Lycée René-Cassin in Strasbourg.With that the students are given the opportunity to get their practical skills certified and, thus, to obtain a more favourable starting position on the labour market. For already three years now, we have been applying the ECVET instruments in co-operation with these partners. In recurrently held workshops we regularly update and adjust the instruments to the corresponding needs.All details described above are mainly applicable to the Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels, except the fact that these students are at the initial stage of their vocational training at the time of their internship. The trainees of the dual educational courses benefit from their three-week internship by testing their practical knowledge in other European countries. The teachers draw upon this experience by improving the quality of their training and to provide the entire staff with the newly gained knowledge and competences. The participants of the project will benefit considerably and sustainably, both, in their professional and private life from the improvement of their language skills, newly gained cultural insights and, last but not least, their personality development. 1 The students of the triennial course do a combined degree course of AVCE and State-certified Commercial Assistant for Foreign Languages.2 Dual courses are a combination of theoretical vocational training at school and practical training in a company.
MY AIM III: Managing Yourself-  Achievement, Inspiration, Motivation
European College of Business and Management

In our recent projects MY AIM and MY AIM II/ OUR AIM the self-management approach has been implemented as an integral element of work placements abroad. Additionally, MY AIM II/ OUR AIM: „Managing Yourself and Organisational Units Restructured: Achievement, Inspiration, Motivation“ has broadened the perspective offering further education to educational staff in schools and companies in order to develop a wider European perspective in vocational training. Focusing our project on more target groups serves the organisational development of our school and our partners in a widening European/ global context. MY AIM III therefore follows a consistent development, continuing the approach of our first projects.
As a certified European School the Berufskolleg Mönchengladbach encourages and supports students in developing  a broad European perspective. Promoting mobility is especially emphasized. The new project MY AIM III is directed at trainees and VET students and aditionally focuses on training staff in schools and companies. We offer participants the possibility to do a work placement in another European country so that they can try out and put into practice their professional, linguistic and personal competences in new challenging contexts.
MY AIM combined central objectives promoted by the ERASMUS+-programme  -  lifelong  learning, further development of employability, internationalisation of professional education as well as recognition and certification of learning outcomes – with a self-management approach. The tools and instruments used in self-management (planning tools, setting objectives, feedback-analysis) are especially suited to develop and expand personal competences in the context of European work placements. The following project MY AIM/ OUR AIM  has aimed at implementing these objectives on all organisational levels: on the individual level of the trainee, on the organisational of the school itself, on the level of cooperations with our partner companies.
ECVET-principles (recognition of learning outcomes, identification of units of learning) and  ECVET-instruments are essential elements of the general project management as well as tools for managing the participants´ learning process.
The new follow-up project MY AIM III seeks to perpetuate this development.

The project MY AIM III will have a decisive influence on:
-  the internationalisation of vocational training concepts
 - the „Europeanisation“ of professional qualifications
- the participants´ abilities to organize and influence their professional development actively, autonomously and self-confidently and to discover broader perspectives regarding their professional mobility
- the cooperating companies to take into account not only purely professional skills, but to a larger extent personal competences 
- the Berufskolleg Volksgartenstraße to focus more on students´ individual competences and learning processes and to develop an even broader European perspective in professional education

The results of MY AIM will be presented to and made available for a broad public.
Internationaler Kaufmann - Neue Wege in der Berufsausbildung für Industriekaufleute
European College of Business and Management

We see our newly prepared course „Internationaler Kaufmann – Neue Wege in der Berufsbildung für Industriekaufleute” as integrated foreign-language training. In advance the students are trained in a plus-programme at our vocational school in terms of data processing, foreign language, sociopolitical topics and giving presentations. In a three-week course at the European College of Business and Management in London, with 26 teaching units a week, the pupils apply their knowledge by giving short talks, preparing power point presentations and writing compositions about economic and politico-economic tasks in English. In addition they have typical Business English units such as correspondence, telephoning and cultural differences. The cross-cultural competence will be improved by several excursions. The written project report (approximately 1500 words) will be completed and edited (text processing, image editing, graphics) after the stay at home. These reports will be passed on to the European College to be assessed. 
The students can acquire three certificates: German-British Chamber Certificate, European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the Europass.
To acquire these certificates the students need to perform the following efforts:
Written project report (approximately 1500 words) after the end of the course at home, a power point presentation about an economic topic, a three hour written test.
We are planning to integrate the results of the mobility in the report marks and the comment of the school certificate of 11th grade. In this connection we want to check to which extent the separate achievements of the mobility can be transferred into report marks. This is what we want to develop in close cooperation with our school management, the Government of Swabia and the Ministry of Education.
Absolutely essential for us is the improvement of the monitoring.
We are planning:
- All steps of preparation being evaluated by the students
- Students take notes of their progress in a project diary
- The host families being evaluated by the students
- The content of the courses and the teachers of the ECBM being assessed
- The professionalism of the project management of the teachers of our school being validated.
In addition we want the whole project to be evaluated by the trainers of the participating KMUs.
As result of the consistent further development of our project series the pupils receive the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” in cooperation with the DIHK Berlin.
The requirements for this certificate, which was developed by the AHK in London, are:
1. Successful conclusion of the apprenticeship to become an industrial clerk
2. Successful completion of the three week mobility in London (PDP-Programme at the ECBM in London (written and oral exam plus essay))
Additionally we demand at least good results in the KMK-Certificate in Business English level 2.
If all qualifications are fulfilled the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” will be carried out by the ECBM in London.
Our business is our future - Enhancing Students’ and Teachers' International Capabilities
European College of Business and Management

Project background and goals
As the meaning of international qualifications on the job market is increasing and as we have more and more students who are asylum seekers at our school we feel the need to qualify our students and staff for an international job environment. Therefore, we want to improve their language, intercultural, personal and professional competences in order to prepare them for the international job market and to contribute to a tolerant and peaceful environment. In the quality agreement of our school we state that our students and teachers should have the chance to spend some time abroad and to acquire international certificates. 
For the long-term realisation of our projects it’s essential to qualify our teachers step by step. We want to enable them to organize and develop European mobility programmes and partnerships and to teach our students language and intercultural skills in a modern way. 

Project description
One step towards this goal is our mobility project “„Our business is our future – Enhancing Students’ and Teachers' International Capabilities“  that we organize in cooperation with the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. Within the next two years  we want to send 40 students  to the United Kingdom. The students do an apprenticeship as a management assistant in retail business, in wholesale and foreign trade or office management assistants. In order to increase their business knowledge, intercultural experience and language skills the students attend an Intensive Course (PDP - Professional Development Programmes) that takes 3 weeks. In the courses they get an overview of British business and culture and an introduction to their specific areas of occupation and interest which can be built upon at a later stage. There are also excursions that have close relevance to the course topics, e.g. to London Stock Exchange, MINI plant in Oxford, Bosch in Denham, The Bank of England Museum or The Thames Barrier. During their stay at British guest families and in London they gain insights in British life and culture and  improve their cross-cultural competence and understanding.

Second, we sent 6 teachers to the ECBM for one week in order to do a job-shadowing, to improve their language and professional skills and to gather information. They will talk to project managers and to students and will make sure that the quality of our project is maintained and optimized. They also monitor and accompany our students in London and are responsible for the organization of excursions and trips. 

Project success and certificates
The success and quality of the project will be monitored and assessed with different instruments. We rely on instruments like the participants and learning agreement according to ECVET-standards to make the project goals measurable and visible. During their stay the students are monitored by our staff and with a set of feedback instruments we make sure that all of our participants meet the project goals. At the end of their stay our students write a test, do an oral presentation and hand in an executive summary. After the course the students get the European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the German-British Chamber Certificate (AHK London). Moreover, after successful completion of their final exams of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK) in Germany they can acquire the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC), which is officially accredited by the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce (AHK) in London.  Moreover, to  validate the competences acquired by the participants during their experiences abroad all participants get the Europass Mobility Document. 
Our teachers also get an attendance certificate of the ECBM  and the Europass. 

Effect
We hope to increase the self-confidence and openness of our participants so that they recognize the meaning of international mobility and to develop their competences. We want to increase their willingness to work with people from other countries and with different cultural backgrounds. We want to contribute to the level of awareness of Erasmus+ projects and share our project results with different stakeholders, like other schools and companies in order to motivate them to take part in an Erasmus activity themselves.
European College of Business and Management

Since 1999 we are conducting the project in London in cooperation with the „“European College of business and Management” (ECBM). We have established the project for the traineeship ‘Investmentfondskaufmann’ and we have been extending it to the benefit of our trainees who will become bank clerks. Having started with 40 participating students we are actually sending 60 students to London.

The title of the project ‘Banking centre London among the shades of the financial crisis’ clearly describes our aim: future bank employees should act faithfully and reliably on international financial places. During their stay in London the students should discover banking centre London with its severe problems. They should learn about British economy, banking centre London und British politics.  Visiting the docklands, the Bank of England and the stock exchange for example our students will make up their mind about London.

Target group of our project are ‘Investmentfondskaufleute’ and ‘Bankkaufleute’ who started their traineeship one year ago. They already passed their intermediate examination and went to vocational school on a block release. Their employers are mainly banks and investments funds companies in Frankfurt.

In London students mainly spend their time in college and getting to know the city as a financial centre. The college works out a training scheme tailored to needs of our students and is responsible for conducting the subjects. The lessons are held by native speakers. Excursions are also a part of the training program. At the end of the stay the students have to pass several exams to get 3 certificates. 

Early planning is very important for us: in September 2014 college, flights and hotel rooms have to be reserved. Booking the flight we also contract a travel cancellation insurance which covers the students’ own contribution of 650 €. For many years now we are guests of the Lancaster Hall Hotel in London and we stick to all of our partners that we are working now for many years. 

It’s our aim that students improve their professional, social, intercultural and linguistic skills. The following vocational and social competences should be expanded: the participants should discover the banking centre London and they should follow the college lessons about economic, political and cultural topics held in the English language. Furthermore they have to live and work with students of other institutions in an unknown surrounding. This requires a high level of social responsibility. The participants will get to know a foreign culture, because London itself is a melting pot of cultures. Going by tube to the college, going to museums is also a part of the students’ intercultural experiences in a very open and tolerant society. In discussions with their professors they will automatically think about the different strategies that both countries have to solve their problems. Since the dominant language in the financial sector is English  the students will gain professional and linguistic profit.

European College of Business and Management

Project background
We are a public vocational school for commercial trainees (1649 students) located in Straubing/Lower Bavaria, 2 Berufsfachschulen are affiliated. We promote our students and emphasise the mediation of learning contents and the students’ linguistic, professional a. personal development. Our school intends to provide optimal conditions for doing so and to develop itself further in regard of quality management and internationalisation. 

Aims
The regional training companies are increasingly operating on a global basis. More and more students think about joining internationally operating companies or working abroad. We would like to offer them opportunities to increase their competences a. working techniques. The mobility “Work experience in Europe III”, implemented with the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) London, contributes to this. 

Number/profile of participants
40 participants in various commercial apprenticeships (incl. tourism, health) with secondary school certificate or higher qualifications as educational background

Activities
This mobility is offered in 2 flows (autumn 2017 and 18). It plans a three week stay in London: 1 week at college, 2 weeks as interns in London companies. Accommodatiion will be at host families.
1st week:
Special crash course at ECBM “Professional Development Programme” (as a group with presentations as final exam)
2nd /3rd week:
10-day business placement, usually 1 intern per company (placement in cooperation with ECBM, a placement agency, our school, the training companies, the participants themselves or companies from Straubing having business relations with England). All companies having an intern name one person in charge, who has to overview the attainment of the learning agreements so that according to the ECVET the agreed on targets will be accomplished.
Each of our students can apply regardless of occupation a. form/grade. Required: letter of motivation in English, Europass CV, language passport, interview in English with the EU-team, KMK-English-Certificate.
Additional culture/leisure programme: Oxford, Windsor, Greenwich, musicals, etc. By experiencing own activities, the students’ self-reliance will improve, too.

Methods of implementation
School administration, English teachers, class teacher, students' representatives a. training companies are involved in the selection process. All participants conclude a detailed contract with highly specified learning agreements a. quality commitments with the sending a. receiving institution.
The participants attend 2 meetings (15 – 20 hours) as well as a Moodle online course (individual, flexible); they get subject-specified input, learn/repeat new facts about the English language, improve their cultural awareness a. organisational talent as well as their social /soft skills. Realisation/management is done by our EU-team. Apart from that all participants work with OLS.
Teachers will be on site as contact persons. They will visit the ECBM and the internship companies for proper monitoring. If necessary, students have to attend a meeting (2/3 times a week) for debriefing.

Evaluation:
Preparation /realisation of this arrangement will be supervised a. evaluated (evaluation form, conversations) by the EU-team. All participants have to keep a record book and the coordinators visit the companies. Questionnaires have to be filled in after their return.

Intended results, impacts , long-term benefits
Participants
• Increase in job-related skills, language and occupational competence
• Higher level of empathy and cultural awareness
• Improvement in communication skills and capability of working in a team
• Positive development of personality and self-reflection
• Using the newly acquired skills (training companies, at school , further professional career)
• Better grades
• Improved application portfolio (updating of Europass CV and language passport, Europass mobility, various certificates)
• Higher competitiveness on the job market
• Increased willingness to work and live abroad
• Long-term ties with companies/host families; new friendships
School 
• Development of our guiding principles
• QMBS-sustainability
• Enlargement of the methodical competences of the EU-team (language, country-specific knowledge, getting to know English companies or job-related parameters...)
• Enhancement of occupational competence by managing the project
• Providing authentic material for class and exchange among the teachers (intranet, further education inside the school, symposia)
• European perspectives for human resource development
• Coming placements for teachers 
• Our school will be positively recognised in public, according to our strategy of internationalisation
Stakeholders
• Interconnectedness /improved cooperation among all institutions involved (Germany a.  abroad)
• Better cooperation with public institutions (eg chambers of commerce, such as IHK/AHK)
• Synergy effects for the business region Straubing
Das PDP-Programm: eine berufliche Zusatzqualifikation zur Verbesserung der interkulturellen Kompetenz und der Internationalisierung der dualen Ausbildung
European College of Business and Management

The emphasis of our current project is on the transition from vocational training to employment and its requirements and challenges. To collect information, data and experiences our students are doing internships in the following three countries: Poland, Finland and Spain. 

Additionally a group of students took part in a professional development course (PDP programme) at the European College for Business and Management (ECBM) in London. The business courses are being taught in English and focus on international business and finance, but also Business English and international competences. After completing the PDP course the students can apply for the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC). It will be awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London), which operates under the umbrella of the German Association of Chambers of Industry and Commerce (Deutscher Industrie- und Handelskammertag, DIHK Berlin). Certificate holders prove that they are able to operate in an international business environment. As the programme was very successful, we would like to send further groups within the next years.

Beside our positive experiences and our well working cooperation the main reasons are:
- deepening the existing knowledge on business topics
- enhancing the knowledge by international aspects and points of view
- practice and improvement of English skills
- learning about business correspondance and intercultural awareness
- broadening of the vocabulary basis (especially concerning technical terms and expressions) - many of the students have chosen  bilingual lessons and are being taught "sales and marketing" in English. Since the courses at the ECBM are mainly about the topic "marketing" it is a great complement to the lessons at the vocational school in Germany
- getting to know the British culture and also other cultures while living with host families
- gaining of a more open-minded and more international point of view
- providing the students with the professional and personal qualifications, skills and knowledge necessary for being able to compete on the international job market in a further together growing Europe

Additionally we would like to send 6 teachers on a one week training course to London. The teachers are going to take part in business and business language modules at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) and will visit the international trade fair "London Bike Show". The reasons behind this visit are: one major topic of the English curriculum of year 11 is the topic "trade fairs". Therefore the teachers get an practical insight into the topic. Another reason is that our vocational school works with a sample company producing bikes. In order to prepare authentic materials for the students and to be able to provide them with the correct tecnical terms and examples which are practice-realted it is important to have contact with bicycle manufacturers and distributers.  Therefor this training course is especially important for the English and CLIL/bilingual teachers of our school. The courses at the ECBM about marketing, sales and business correspondance will round off the programme. 

To sum up our plans the project will underline and support the internationalisation of our school and of our students and it rounds off our programme of work experiences abroad, international certificates and bilingual lessons.
European College of Business and Management

For implementing the strategy of internationalisation we will continue the mobility projects which we have already executed for the past few years and add two more projects. Our established projects and our new ones are the following ones:I. 2 Flows consisting of 46 apprentices to London1. Backround of the project:The Kaufmännische Berufsschule IV sends students to the ECBM, located in London. These students work in the field of business administration and are involved in an international working area.That´s why staying abroad would mean a lot to them, both for their professional and personal future. The project is run in two flows:1st flow: 14.05.17 - 03.06.172nd flow: 03.06.18 - 23.06.182. The aim of the project:All participants are expected to improve their professional and social competences, their cultural awareness and also their language skills.3. Number and profile of participants:In each flow 23 participants from all different professional guilds take part.4. Description of activities:- Preparation- Students are hosted by guest families and have to take part in school lessons at ECBM. - They will work in groups, doing Internet research while preparing a final project work dealing with a predetermined topic. - They participate in excursions and different cultural programmes. - In the end they all have to pass a final exam, which consists of 1. a written test, 2. an oral test and 3. a project work.- Monitoring- Evaluation5. Methodology:All participants have the chance to improve their above-mentioned competences and skills. They broaden their horizon by taking part in actively held school lessons and also by experiencing the everyday life in a foreign country. 6. Results, long- term effects and benefits of the project:- All participants get the chance to improve their competences and chances on the international labour market.- Companies benefit from training of their human resources.- The local area remains competitive as compared to international standards.- The unemployment among youth can be reduced.7. ECVET - Europass Mobility/CV, Learning agreements  and various Certificates- Learning agreements with all students and signed by all partners- Europass Mobility/CV for the students to document the Mobilty Activity- the students get also further certificates to document the activities by the ECBM and the German-British ChamberII. 2 apprentices will go to Spain to participate in a four-weeks learning and training programme. Up to now we only conducted 2 weeks programmes in our partner institution. It is our intention to send 2 apprentices -minimum- each year to Spain, to get to know our partner institution and to take part in a training programme in companies for 2 weeks. Also our partners want the exchange projects and will send 3 apprenteces to us at our school.III. This year we will start an exchange programme with our partner institution "Institut de Vic" which aims exactly at our colleagues of our vocational college or perhaps some neighbouring schools as well. We would like our colleagues to aquire some knowledge about the educational programme especially in the vocational area which is perfomed in Spain and Catalonia. They should get to know our partner institution in Vic as well as the colleagues who are teaching there and the whole institution. We would like them to to build up contacts there. We will start this programme with a small group of 6 teachers, that they will be able to act as future multipliers. We do this according to our mission statement. We do hope that our partners will also get the funding in Spain, that we can welcome our Spanish friends here as well.This is our strategy for internationalisation especially for the application in 2016. We are dealing on two levels at the moment, on the level of the teachers of vocational training and on the level of apprentices. In the oncoming years we will try to develop further programmes and we are focusing on Northern ireland as already outlined in our charta application
Fachspezifischer Trainingskurs für kaufmännische Auszubildende in Großbritannien
European College of Business and Management

Due to the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of the working environment it has become more and more important in recent years to prepare the trainees for these challenges in their various jobs. Confident communication with foreign partners requires good knowledge in the world language English on the one hand and on the other hand also a high degree of intercultural competence. Our projects contribute to support our trainees especially in the above mentioned aspects which also corresponds to our school internal quality management understanding (“Schulinternes Qualitätsverständnis – SQV”). After having offered a language course for industrial clerk, bank clerk and office administration clerk trainees at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London for the past years we have now taken the decision to offer a practical training for retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees with B.I.G. Bristol. “Project 1” mentioned in this application form is the course at the ECBM, “Project 2” is the practical training with B.I.G. Bristol.

After getting in contact with the European College of Business and Management by the recommendation of another vocational school, various teachers of our school took part in a further education course at the ECBM. The experiences we gained there concretised the planning of an own project which was implemented the year after. Both the economic and pedagogic skills of the teachers at the ECBM concerning the transmission of central aspects of the British economy, culture and politics have convinced us to continue this project for more than ten years now.

The decision of offering another project (project 2) has prompted us to choose B.I.G. Bristol as a further partner organisation for retail clerk respectively wholesale clerk trainees. We got familiar with this company during a further education course about “Leonardo DaVinci”. B.I.G. Bristol organise practical trainings which meet the job requirements of our retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees.

The main aim of project 1 is to enable 24 students from the vocational school "Staatliche Berufsschule II Memmingen" to attend a three-weeks course at the European College of Business and Management in London. The students, who train to be a bank clerk, industrial clerk or office clerk, are all in their second year of vocational training. During the course the students are able to improve their language skills in English as well as their knowledge in business administration issues.

At the college the students attend lessons every working day between 9.30 am and 4.45 pm. The lessons deal with topics which are related to their vocational training in Germany. The lessons are held by specially trained and experienced teachers from the college. In addition to the daily lessons, the participants have to write out an assignment on a special economic or social-economic topic, which is chosen by them individually. This as well as the final presentation at the end of the course, enhances the language skills immensely.

Concerning project 2, 20 wholesale and retail clerk trainees take part in a two-week internship in various commercial companies. They will get a close insight into the job-related practical experience and get the chance to interchange with their British colleagues. 

Next to the course, the students of both projects are obliged to plan and prepare several group excursions. The group leaders decide on relevant topics and talk them over with the students during the preparation meetings. The topics are then prepared in English by the student teams, so that they can be presented by them in London respectively Bristol and the surrounding area during the group excursions. 

Another major aim of the project is to enlarge the intercultural, social and individual skills of the students. They enter a new field with unknown cultural and social requirements, they learn to communicate and to cooperate with students and teachers. Both the projects in London and Bristol focus on the strategy of internationalisation and especially concentrate on an increase of mobility of the students, teachers and employers as well as the internationalisation of the “Berufsschule II Memmingen”.
Professional International Training für Großhändler II
European College of Business and Management

Background and aims of the project:
This Erasmus-Project follows a request of the commercial department of our school from 2016.
This project started with the thoughts, to offer our wholesalers a contemporary, approved, job-related advanced training in an English-speaking environment.
The European College of Business and Commerce (ECBM) is located in the heart of the city of London with its international financial and commercial districts as the cultural sights.
It is an ideal starting point for everybody, who wants to collect experiences in the British, European and international business and cultural community.
The project is linked with our curriculum and the expectations of our companies.
Our main-target is to impart job-related, intercultural and linguistic skills to our participants in lessons and excursions.  This shall secure their chances on the international employment market. The involved companies are especially looking forward to the intense training program with the exams for the "international businessman" at the end of the project.

Number and profile of the participants:

At each flow there will be 20 apprentices participating from mainly medium-sized wholesaler-companies. Most of them take part in the project at the beginning of their second year at school. Some of them could already participate at exchange-programs in their former schools, but up to now, they had no chance to collect job-related experiences abroad.

Organization and implementation:

1. Preparation:

In the preparation we discuss with Sarah Iles (ECBM) the content of the course, adjust them with the curriculum and sign the contract with the ECBM (ECVET). We inform the companies, select the participants, determine the learning agreements (ECVET), organize the flights and the airport-transfer, conclude the insurances and prepare the participants intensively for their stay in London.

2. Project:
During the activity the ECBM will be responsible for transfers, selection of host families, the course-program, excursions and evaluations. The attending teacher will work closely with the teachers of the ECBM and secure the transfers of our students.
 
3. Post-processing:

In the post-processing the participants will evaluate the project and present their experiences to the other students and prospective participants. So we can ensure to go on with the project and to enrich the lessons in school. They write articles for the annual report at school and the local newspapers. Additionally we will complete their EUROPASS-documents. 


It is our main aim, to intensify the job-related knowledge and skills on an international way and to increase the linguistic skills of the participants, to encourage their willingness to achieve life-long learning and mobility.

According to the statements of the IHK companies are forced to raise their international activities in case of acquisition and sales.
The vocational skills of the employees should be prepared for this development.
Linguistic skills in English, the international language of commerce, and knowledge of typical economic structures of an important trading-partner will be a competitive advantage for our wholesalers.

Our aim is to continue and to intensify our cooperation with the ECBM. Each year shall 20 motivated apprentices take part in this project. For the involved teachers means the close cooperation with the ECBM a possibility to interchange information and ideas on an European level and to receive an insight to the global trading point London 
These experiences and perceptions will be enrich the normal vocational lessons in Germany.

The ECBM project is supposed to be a further part of our strategy to internationalize our school. We will - as we did it in earlier projects as Brigit-compass, Yeast and PROFIT I - work responsibly with the allocated support to broaden the benefit for our students.
Die Eurokrise und der Finanzplatz London
European College of Business and Management

Since 1999 we have been conducting the project in London in cooperation with the „“European College of Business and Management” (ECBM). We have established the project for the apprentices of Investment Fund Administration and we have been extending it to the benefit of our apprentices in Banking. Having started with 40 participating students we are now sending 60 students to London.

The title of the project ‘The financial centre of London affected by the €-crisis’ clearly describes our aim: future bank employees should be able to act responsibly and reliably at international financial places. During their stay in London the students are supposed to discover the banking centre London with its severe problems as well as learn about British economy and politics.  Visiting the docklands, the Bank of England and the Stock Exchange, for example, our students will get a deeper insight into London.

The target group of our project are apprentices of Investment Fund Administration and apprentices in Banking who started their traineeship one year ago. They have already passed their intermediate examination and have received theoretical training in form of block teaching in our vocational school. Their employers are mainly banks and investment fund companies in Frankfurt.

In London students mainly spend their time in college and get to know the city as a financial centre. The college works out a training scheme tailored to needs of our students and is responsible for teaching the subjects. The lessons are held by native speakers. Excursions are also a part of the training programme. At the end of the stay the students have to pass several exams to receive three certificates:
- Certificate of the ECBM 
- Certificate of the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce
- Kaufmann/Kauffrau International (AHK)

Early planning is very important for us: in September 2015 the college, the flights and the hotel rooms have to be reserved. When booking the flight we also apply for a travel cancellation insurance which covers the students’ own contribution of 650 euros. For many years now we have been guests at the Lancaster Hall Hotel in London and we have been working with the college and our travel agency. 

It’s our aim that students improve their professional, social, intercultural and linguistic skills. The following vocational and social competences should be expanded: the participants should discover the banking centre London and they should follow the college lessons about economic, political and cultural topics held in English. Furthermore they have to live and work with students of other institutions in an unknown surrounding. This requires a high level of social responsibility. The participants will get to know a foreign culture, because London itself is a melting pot of cultures. Going to the college by tube or going to museums are also part of the students’ intercultural experiences in a very open and tolerant society. In discussions with their professors they will automatically think about the different strategies that the two countries have to solve their problems. Since the dominant language in the financial sector is English  the students will gain professional as well as linguistic profit.
European College of Business and Management

As a background, the "Berufsschule II Kempten" is currently in the process of evaluating and updating its strategic direction. During this evaluation, an opportunity for growth regarding its international orientation was observed.  The increasing importance of international work experience as part of a successful future work profile is widely recognised. Based on this realisation the German Parliament decided in 2013, that the goal is to enable at least 10% of all apprentices to gain international work experience in some form.  The predominantly small and medium sized company landscape in the region of Kempten/Allgaeu, allows for rather limited opportunities for students to gather international experience e.g. in foreign subsidiaries. As a result, the BS II Kempten decided on integrating the “international orientation” into its set of targets. Concrete goal is to support more students, in cooperation with their employers, to gather international work experience.

After analysing the demand and defining the strategic goal, available resources to meet the targets were evaluated. As a key result, the main concern is the financial feasibility for the students. As a consequence, this application form was put together. With the financial support of the Erasmus+ programme for the apprentices, the vocational School Kempten II would be enabled to reinforce an international awareness within its organization by  establishing an annual mobility project and therefore support the Bundestagsbeschluss from 2013. By organizing this annual mobility the school  can realize its target of "international orientation". 

What exactly does that mean? The BS II Kempten is planning to introduce an annual student mobility activity for 22 students from the professions Bank, Industry, Logistics,  Wholesale and IT. Our partnering institution is the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) based in London. The ECBM is the educational academy of the German-British Chamber of industry and commerce. It already proofed to be extremely reliable and experienced, which supports our selection as a partnering institution. 

Every year the 22 participants of the mobility will take part in an especially designed 3-week “Professional Development Programme (PDP)”. Besides the in-depth examination of various topics in business, politics and society from a European and international perspective, the programme will touch on multiple functional and cross-functional topics. The housing of the students will be realized in guest families. Benefit of this is twofold; the students will dive deep into the British culture as well as significantly improve their language skills.
With the participation in the PDP the apprentices have the possibility to receive the KIC (Kaufmann International Certificate). This prestigious international qualification will be achieved by an oral and a written exam, as well as a dissertation. Additional requirement for this certificate is the graduation of the commercial apprenticeship in Germany. Furthermore all students will obtain the "Europass Mobility" as a record of the acquired competences. In combination with the "Europass CV" (which will already be created by the students in the project application process) these documents constitute the foundation for future application possibilities all over Europe. 

A multilevel application procedure is conducted for the selection of the participants. A specific preparation phase, the mentoring of the students in London and the reflexion phase at the end of the mobility project are further important components. Rounded up is the mobility by the ceremonial award of the "Europass Mobilität", where not only the participants but also the school management and administration, the staff and the cooperative companies will be invited. The realisation of the project is accompanied by a project management concept that helps to ensure the success of the project. Especially appropriate evaluation tools should support the continuous improvement process of further Mobilities. 

The expected impact of the project is multidimensional. The apprentices will not only achieve a substantial increase in different competences, but also experience a leap in their personality development. Taking part in an Erasmus+ Programme improves particularly self-confidence and proactivity in young adults. The mobility is also expected to have an impact on family, friends, school staff and the cooperative companies. By being involved in a mobility project, even if it is just in a passive way, people will be more aware of the importance of the European idea and the peaceful international cooperation. This project has the chance to make a continuing contribution to a more conscious international orientation of the "Berufsschule II Kempten".
European College of Business and Management

General overview:The staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen (vocational training school) is planning to send twenty German students as well as three German teachers from its economics department to London for three weeks. During that time, they will be working at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM). The ECBM is the training college for the German-British Chamber of Commerce. It was founded in 1988 and is well established in the fields of basic and continuous training. They offer the "Professional Development Programme" (PDP), a 3-week, intensive course, which is tailored to our students. During the PDP, our students will complete and earn the certificate of “international businessperson”. This certificate is awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London). This is supposed to ensure that the qualifications and skills gained abroad will improve the student’s chances in the job market and that the experiences abroad will have a lasting effect. Selection process:The selection process for the project will be taking place in two different ways. Students from the economics department taking part in the additional qualification "foreign language correspondence clerk" offered by the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, will be part of the project as well as other applicants from the economics department. All participating students are obliged to hand in a letter of motivation as well as the Europass Curriculum Vitae as well as the Europass Language passport.The participating teachers in the project are being chosen on the basis of their willingness to take part in the project. In the long term, the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen is planning to extend the circle of people as it is one of the main objectives of the school to introduce an internationalisation strategy.Main objectives of the project, concerning students and teachers:Enhancing professional skills and competences:One key objective of the project is a further qualification of the trainees of our economics department. Many of them are doing their traineeship in international companies. Therefore, they should gain job-related experience abroad as soon as possible. Gaining insight into international business processes and using English as the language of business are elements that give these students a professional and personal advantage. Therefore, we are helping our students to be successful on the European labour market. Our teachers, taking part in the project gain insights in planning and conducting European projects and exchange skills and methods with English-speaking colleagues.Developing personal skills and competences:Besides, spending time abroad is helping the students to overcome fears of foreign things and helps them to gain intercultural competences. Our students live in small villages in rural Upper Bavaria. Spending three weeks in multicultural London will make a huge impression on them. Besides, working and living abroad in host families will contribute to a positive personal development. That will also help to promote tolerance and to eliminate prejudices.Our teachers also profit from staying abroad and strengthen their insights into the European idea. Intercultural competences can only be communicated if one is convinced of the idea oneself.Objectives of the project, concerning the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen and its partners:The staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen wants to establish an internationalisation strategy. We want to create a network of national and international partners, from which everyone (companies, students, teacher, and our foreign partners) can profit. Even though, the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen is located in the prosperous region north of Munich, which is constantly profiting from a steady influx of people, demographic change has got an impact on all institutions in vocational training. As a consequence, we see internationalisation as a chance to improve our chances as well as those of our partners in the economy to get highly motivated, productive and cosmopolitan trainees.
Kaufmann/Kauffrau International (AHK) - Vorbereitung auf die Internationalisierung der Arbeitswelt
European College of Business and Management

The project with the title "Kaufmann/Kauffrau International (AHK) - preparation for the internationalisation of the business world" is conducted by the two project partners Staatliche Berufsschule Schwabach and European College of Business and Management (ECBM). To ensure the quality of the cooperation the two partners use ECVET-elements (Memorandum of Understanding, Learning Agreement, Europass Mobility).

As part of the project 20 office management assistants respectively 20 industrial management assistants complete the three week Intensive Professional Development Programme (PDP) provided by the ECBM in London. The PDP-Programme was especially developed for students of vocational schools. It imparts language competence as well as comprehensive competence in the area of management. It is especially the aim of the project to increase the business knowledge, experience and language skills.

Industrial management assistants are deployed in companies of any kind and size. They are responsible for the planning, realisation and control of diverse areas of business responsibilities. It is the aim that an industrial management assistant can handle all business tasks. Due to the international movement of goods two qualifications are becoming more and more important - extended knowledge of foreign languages and intercultural competences.

The newly developed training for office management assistants puts special emphasis on the internationalisation of the trainees. Office management assistants organise and deal with office tasks i.e. they handle business management activities such as purchase order processing, purchasing, accounting, marketing and personnel management. The fields of activity are very diverse: office management assistants can work for industrial companies and trading companies as well as for public service or business associations.

As part of the internationalisation of the business world the requirements that are made on trainees are increasing. The requirements include foreign language competence, openness for other cultures, self-dependence as well as internationally recognized degrees and the readiness for international employment.

The training companies of the Berufsschule Schwabach have production facilities, suppliers and customers within Europe and outside Europe. That's why the companies set high value on the ability to communicate, foreign language competences and intercultural competences. Therefore the practical and intensive application of English and the improvement of the students' communication skills are expected to be advanced and deepened by this project. Another aspect is that the students gain insight into another culture, another way of living and another business world. The participants of the project experience another way of living by staying with a host family. This helps them to reduce potentially existing prejudices towards other cultures.

In a working environment that is growing together closer and closer it won't be enough in the future to possess only a national degree. As a vocational school it is our duty to show that development to our students again and again. The PDP-programme provides the opportunity to gain the internationally recognized degree Kaufmann/Kauffrau International (AHK). The students are also encouraged to think outside the box and to take international employment opportunities into consideration.
Doing Business in the Intercultural Environment
European College of Business and Management

The mobility project entitled " Doing Business in the Intercultural Environment" offers 20 participants of the OSZ II Spree -Neisse the opportunity to gain knowledge about the European economic and financial system and moreover to deepen and expand the foreign language skills. It offers the oppotunity for some teachers of our vocational school to deepen their knowledge about business and management and methods to teach it. The project is being prepared on OSZ II Spree -Neisse, will be carried out at the European College of Business and Management London over three weeks and evaluated after return.In connection with this course, 20 participants create a project work in English whose theme is proposed by ECBM London or can be chosen by the participant in consultation with the training organization itself. Basically topics include dealing with the economic and social developments within the European Economic Area.At the end of the stay, all participants will present their project work at ECBM London using modern media and pass a written examination on the taught subjects. The project work will be completed at home as executive summary and sent back to the ECBM London for evaluation.After successful completion, all participants will receive at least two certificates. A certificate of German Chamber of Industry and Commerce in London (AHK London) and a certificate of participation by the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London on the topics dealt with.In addition, any commercial participants may apply for and acquire the title of "Kauffrau/mann International" after successful completion of their professional training.Each participant will receive the Europass Mobility. So they have better chances to work in business and to get a job because a good command of English is demanded by a lot of companies and institutions nowadays.The results of the project work will be presented at our school in English in classes of the relevant professional groups and serve as a basis for discussion.Insights into the mobility project provide e.g. the publication of an online diary on our website, presentations to the staff of employers, the photo gallery in the school building, discussions at the European Week each May.Meanwhile we have conducted five of such projects since 2010. The Mobility Project has become an integral part of our school programme and encourages many people in our region to consider Europe as an economic area and to take courage to be self- mobile.
European College of Business and Management

Ulm Chamber of Commerce and Industry (IHK Ulm) is submitting an application to offer trainees in commercial occupations requiring formal traning the oppertunity to acquire the additional qualification "international merchant" (AHK) in a three-week stay in London. The application is being submitted by two institutions: Ulm Chamber of Commerce and Industry (sending organisation) and the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in England, London (receiving organisation)Ulm Chamber of Commerce and Industry is a self-regulatory body of the regional economy with approximentely 30.000 mebmer companies in the administrative districts of Alb-Donau and Biberach as well as in the urban district of Ulm.  Chamber of Commerice and Industry is a contact for all business matters. It is committed to an extensive and high-quality range of educational oppertunities and for more quality in the educational system. Only with a sufficient choice of well qualified specialist workers will our companies be able to survive in international competition due to innovations and new technologies in future as well. For thies reason, IHK Ulm is committed to good education in all educatinal areas.According to forecasts, the economically strong chamber of commerce and industry region of Ulm will be affected to an aboveaverage extent by the lack of specialist workers. Here, in turn, the lack of specialist workers will particulary hit SMEs. The dual vocational training system is acquiring particular importance of securing the young crop of specialist workers. Here, it will be particularly important to gain school leavers for vocational training. This is possible only with specail additional offerings that serve to promote talent at the same time. Stay abroad for the purpose of using and improving foreign language skills as well as improving knowledge of international economic relations are ideal for preparing qualified commercial trainess for challenging roles at international companies.In the long term, Ulm Chamber of Commerce and Industry intends to use such projects to make the dual vocational training system attracitve for young people and also for companies. It also aims to preserve well qualified specialist workers for the region through the additional qualification and thus cover the need for specialist workers in their region.The partner institution European College offers a professional development programme, an intensive course for trainees with the objective of acquiring the additional qualification of international merchant (AHK).The target group of this project is commercial trainess in their first odersecond year of training in a dual vocational training course. The companies at which the trainess complete their training mostly have transnational connecations or foreign customer contacts. IHK Ulm will carry out a 3-week stay in London with 25 participants in June 2017 and with 25 participant in May/June 2018.  All two stays abroad serve the acquistion of the additional qualification AHK "international merchant". The participants take part in an intensive course at the ECBM in London. The intensive course consists of theoretical knowledge impartation and excursions such as company visits, etc. in order to increase and demonstrate knowledge in practice. In this programme, knowledge of the British economy and knowledge of trade and politics is acquired. Above all, foreign language skills are expanded and intensified and the participants gain intercultural experience. At the end of the courese, a three-stage exanimation is sat for the additional qualification of "international merchant".Ulm Chamber of Commerce and Industry will publish regular reports in the press on this project so that a wide public is informed about the project
European College of Business and Management

Context/ Background to the project: In cooperation with the European College of Business and Management, the Staatliche Berufsschule Ostallgäu (State Vocational School of the Ostallgäu Region) has planned and designed a three-week tailor-made training course for commercial apprentices. This course aims to enable interested students to complete a vocational, linguistic and cultural advanced training beyond the scope of their daily work and school life.Aims of the project:On the one hand, the course is aimed at improving the participants’ language skills in specific vocational and general topics. On the other hand, by providing them with an insight into the British economic capital, the apprentices will have a chance to widen their perspectives beyond their own/national experience and thus be more able to contribute to the development of the European community.Number/Profiles of the participants: Every year, 22 young people, who are completing their first apprenticeship in different commercial professions, participate in this course. The students are aged between 17 and 22 years (depending on their educational background). As the participants are from different commercial courses, many of the group members first get to know each other during the four preparatory meetings.Description of the activities: In a preparatory phase lasting approx. 6 months, the supervising teachers prepare the apprentices intensively for the training course during four preparatory meetings, in order to ensure productive work at the College. During the three-week stay in London, different lecturers from the College - together with the participants - will work on subjects in English, such as: presentation skills, business correspondence, the modern British economy, business ethics, corporate social responsibility, career development opportunities etc. During a three-hour exam in their third project week, the students will be tested on the knowledge aquired about the topics they have dealt with. In addition, at the end of the training course, the participants have to make a presentation in English about a previously chosen topic, which will be marked together with the summary that has to be handed in. Apart from school activities, the lecturers make various topic-related field trips together with the apprentices. Furthermore, two companies will be visited in order to gain an insight into the work environment of the financial centre of London. To round things off, guided city tours and visits to theatres and museums are offered as well. Despite the wide range of the course content, it is also important for us that the young people still have the possibility to explore the cosmopolitan city of London on their own and come to terms with a multicultural population. For this reason, the accommodation in host families – in a foreign-language environment – has proved itself to be very valuable.Methods: It is agreed with the College that the three-week training course is instructed and accompanied by lecturers and supervising teachers. However, the participants have to complete their tasks independently and on their own responsibility.Lasting advantages which can be expected by participating in this project:1) Informing others in their company, school and private surroundings of the many impressions they have gained: these young people come back to their familiar environment with new and diverse experiences from abroad. In doing so, they pass on their impressions to their families, friends and acquaintances which leads to a widening of general interest. The companies feel encouraged in their active support when they recognize that their apprentices have improved noticeably in all areas. Thus, very often, new enquiries from the training companies regarding future projects arise only shortly afterwards. In school, the students present their project work to their classmates in English and thereby awaken their curiosity and earn additional respect because of their good performance.2) Expansion of professional/personal perspectives: Experience shows that the young students returning from the three-week programme in London are more self-confident, balanced and motivated. In many cases, their attitudes towards other cultures have changed and their wish to have further experiences abroad has grown.3) Increased professional/personal opportunities: Dealing intensively with cultural, linguistic and vocational matters in a foreign environment, the students who complete this course will gain new opportunities in their professional as well as in their private lives. Their improved foreign language skills, which can be presented to any (future) employer with the Certificate and the Europass Mobility, provide an undeniable advantage compared to other applicants. Many of the participants can imagine working or studying abroad in the foreseeable future. In terms of studying, the ECBM offers a Bachelor degree course.
Internationaler Kaufmann - Neue Wege in der Berufsausbildung für Industriekaufleute
European College of Business and Management

We see our newly prepared course „Internationaler Kaufmann – Neue Wege in der Berufsbildung für Industriekaufleute” as integrated foreign-language training. In advance the students are trained in a plus-programme at our vocational school in terms of data processing, foreign language, sociopolitical topics and giving presentations. In a three-week course at the European College of Business and Management in London, with 26 teaching units a week, the pupils apply their knowledge by giving short talks, preparing power point presentations and writing compositions about economic and politico-economic tasks in English. In addition they have typical Business English units such as correspondence, telephoning and cultural differences. The cross-cultural competence will be improved by several excursions. The written project report (approximately 1500 words) will be completed and edited (text processing, image editing, graphics) after the stay at home. These reports will be passed on to the European College to be assessed. 
The students can acquire three certificates: German-British Chamber Certificate, European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the Europass.
To acquire these certificates the students need to perform the following efforts:
Written project report (approximately 1500 words) after the end of the course at home, a power point presentation about an economic topic, a three hour written test.
We are planning to integrate the results of the mobility in the report marks and the comment of the school certificate of 11th grade. In this connection we want to check to which extent the separate achievements of the mobility can be transferred into report marks. This is what we want to develop in close cooperation with our school management, the Government of Swabia and the Ministry of Education.
Absolutely essential for us is the improvement of the monitoring.
We are planning:
- All steps of preparation being evaluated by the students
- Students take notes of their progress in a project diary
- The host families being evaluated by the students
- The content of the courses and the teachers of the ECBM being assessed
- The professionalism of the project management of the teachers of our school being validated.
In addition we want the whole project to be evaluated by the trainers of the participating KMUs.
As result of the consistent further development of our project series the pupils receive the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” in cooperation with the DIHK Berlin.
The requirements for this certificate, which was developed by the AHK in London, are:
1. Successful conclusion of the apprenticeship to become an industrial clerk
2. Successful completion of the three week mobility in London (PDP-Programme at the ECBM in London (written and oral exam plus essay))
Additionally we demand at least good results in the KMK-Certificate in Business English level 2.
If all qualifications are fulfilled the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” will be carried out by the ECBM in London.

Kaufmännische Auszubildende in England und in Estland
European College of Business and Management

The Kaufmännische Schulen 1 Villingen-Schwenningen (KS1) would like to enable young apprentices to get work experience abroad as part of their dual training (e.g. as industrial clerks or financial assistants). The aim of this is an increased intercultural and personal competence to help master new challenges in business as well as personal life. Businesses, which are very often internationally orientated, would thus benefit from highly motivated employees who would be more self-assured in their treatment of foreign customers and suppliers. Participation in the project can also lead to enhanced willingness to work abroad inside the EU.

The project is aimed at students with university entry qualification and those entitled to study at specialist colleges and universities of applied sciences, whose level of proficiency in English is at least B2 (for Great Britain), and good students who graduated from middle school with a sound knowledge of English, which they can use to bridge communication gaps (for Estonia). The participants will be apprentices of various different professions in their second year of training. The focus will be on bank clerks, industrial clerks as well as clerks in administration, but the project will be open to all other professions, like office clerks and automotive clerks. At the time of departure, students in three-year courses will have passed about one half of their training, those in two-year courses (e.g. financial assistants) will have passed about two-thirds of their training.
